posts.text:
Everyday Health Type 2 Diabetes How Shared Medical Appointments Helped One Woman Reverse Diabetes With diabetes support groups, and having appointments with all of her diabetes specialists at once, she was able to lose weight and lower her A1C, returning to prediabetes status. Medically Reviewed by Justin Laube, MD Don't Miss This Sign Up for Our Living with Diabetes Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit We respect your privacy . A multidisciplinary approach to diabetes can be an effective way to get your blood sugar under control, research shows. Photo Courtesy of Ethelyn Gavin 
When Ethelyn Gavin was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, what was at first a manageable condition soon took a turn for the worse. As Gavin’s weight escalated, her hemoglobin A1C level — a measure of average blood sugar level over two to three months — became progressively worse, and Gavin’s doctor prescribed oral medication. Over time, she began to experience potentially serious diabetes complications involving other body systems, including her kidney function and increasing fatigue. 
“Diabetes is a tricky disease because you really don’t feel a lot of what is happening inside your body until your other vital organs start to break down,” says Gavin, a former operations manager at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. “It’s like a time bomb.” 
Gavin had experienced a history of yo-yo dieting, which refers to losing weight in the short term but having difficulty keeping that weight off. These fluctuations exacerbated her type 2 diabetes and put her at risk for even more complications , and yet she found staying motivated to stick with any one program to be incredibly difficult. 
“After I retired, it really got out of control,” Gavin says. “My weight escalated dramatically.” 
Finally, Gavin got to the place where she could no longer manage her blood sugar with oral medication alone, and her physician had to ask her: Was she ready to start injecting insulin ? 
“For me, that was the point of no return,” Gavin says. “That was the decision point.” Something had to change. Joining a Weight Management Program to Regain Control 
To help manage her weight and diabetes , Gavin began attending the Cleveland Clinic’s Weight Management Program, which she says was a “last-ditch effort” to stave off having to add insulin injections to her treatment plan. 
The program doesn’t focus only on dieting and exercise, like traditional wellness programs do, she explains — instead, it allows patients to meet with healthcare providers, like an endocrinologist and a registered dietitian, in a shared medical environment. It also includes group sessions with peers who have similar diagnoses and are also trying to manage their blood sugar and weight. 
“You don’t have such a feeling of isolation,” she says. “We’re all in it together.” Plus, there’s a clinical benefit: Sometimes, Gavin explains, another patient may bring up an issue that she would have forgotten to mention to her doctor. “There have been quite a few ‘aha’ moments for me, moments that I realized for myself that there were things I didn’t even understand or recognize.” 
In addition, every month the doctors and dietitians introduce participants to a new educational topic about their diet or disease management , says Abed Alwahab, MD , an endocrinologist at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio, who has treated Gavin. For example, doctors might lead the five or six patients in the program through a cooking class to help them learn healthy recipes . 
Another one of the benefits of these shared medical appointments? As Gavin lost weight, her endocrinologist was able to immediately adjust her medication , she says. Her doctors could monitor her closely and manage her lab work, watching for changes in kidney function . She could also bring about changes to her diet immediately based on feedback from these doctors and lab tests. 
For instance, through counseling, Gavin discovered that she was a grazer, meaning that she would constantly eat but not necessarily sit down to meals — something she worked to change to improve her blood sugar management . Gavin also now aims to move more and has worked her way up to about 5,000 steps a day, often just by making simple changes like parking her car further away from the store, walking the perimeter of a grocery store before walking up and down the aisles, and taking the stairs instead of the elevator. 
“She is one of the many successful stories that we have,” says Dr. Alwahab, calling Gavin a “role model for others.” The Benefits of Shared Doctors’ Appointments for Diabetes 
Studies support the idea that shared medical appointments can lead to better results for people with chronic diseases like diabetes. 
In a review published in January 2015 in the Journal of General Internal Medicine , for example, researchers analyzed 25 articles involving 17 studies that compared shared medical appointments with traditional care, and found that among those people with diabetes, the shared appointment model led to better improvements in A1C scores and blood pressure readings. 
Also, patients who do shared medical appointments are more likely to report higher satisfaction rates with their care when compared with patients who receive traditionally structured care, according to a study published in July 2014 in the journal Annals of Family Medicine . 
The multidisciplinary-team approach can be successful in part by making sure that doctors have access to all relevant information about their care, says Nuha El Sayed, MD , staff physician at the Joslin Diabetes Center in Boston, who has not treated Gavin. “Having a team of different disciplines creates a wealth of opportunity to know our patients better and to serve them better,” she says. 
Dr. El Sayed notes that while shared medical appointments are most common in larger academic settings, like at the Cleveland Clinic or the Harvard-affiliated Joslin Diabetes Center, some smaller clinics also form miniature multidisciplinary teams, in which providers wear multiple hats. 
If you haven’t tried the model, consider asking your physician about options in your hometown, El Sayed recommends. And if shared medical appointments aren’t feasible, you can still reap many of the benefits by encouraging communication among your endocrinologist, dietitian, general physician, and mental health professional, she explains. It’s all about advocating for your health. Reversing Diabetes and Continuing to Control Blood Sugar 
For Gavin, the decision to take part in the Cleveland Clinic’s multidisciplinary care option, through the Weight Management Program, was a turning point. 
Thanks to the approach, Gavin has halved the amount of medication she needs to take to control her diabetes, and she says she is no longer at risk of needing injections of insulin so long as she continues successfully managing her health as she has. 
“I’ve actually returned to prediabetes status,” she says, noting that her blood sugar control has vastly improved. The American Diabetes Association notes that an A1C of 6.5 percent and above signals diabetes, while an A1C between 5.7 and 6.4 indicates prediabetes. 
“My life has changed,” Gavin says. “My outlook on life has changed. I have hope for the future, because of the changes in my health that resulted from participation in the program.” Last Updated:

posts.title: What You Need to Know About Psoriatic Arthritis and Your Weight | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Everyday Health Psoriatic Arthritis What You Need to Know About Psoriatic Arthritis and Your Weight Being overweight can increase your risk of developing psoriatic arthritis and make it harder to manage the condition. Medically Reviewed by Sanjai Sinha, MD Don't Miss This Sign Up for Our Living with Psoriasis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit The connection between weight and psoriatic arthritis differs from person to person. iStock.com 
Excess weight has been linked to many health concerns, including psoriatic disease. “People with psoriatic arthritis and psoriasis are more likely to be overweight,” says Eric Ruderman, MD , clinical practice director of rheumatology at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. But exactly how weight and psoriatic arthritis are connected is complicated and not the same for everyone. Weight's Inflammatory Effect as a Risk Factor 
Being overweight or obese can be a risk factor for developing psoriatic arthritis , especially if you already have psoriasis . Research published in May 2012 in the journal Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases found that, as compared with people with psoriasis who had a normal body mass index (BMI) of less than 25, individuals with a BMI classified as obese (30 to 34.9) had a 22 percent increased risk of developing psoriatic arthritis. People with a BMI of 35 or higher had a 48 percent increased risk. 
The inflammatory effects of excess weight may explain, in part, the increased risk for psoriatic disease. “Obesity has adverse metabolic effects that drive inflammation, leading to accelerated joint damage,” says Elliot Rosenstein, MD , co-medical director of the Institute for Rheumatic and Autoimmune Diseases at Atlantic Health System’s Overlook Medical Center in Summit, New Jersey. Fat tissue releases proteins known as cytokines that trigger inflammation. This inflammation can cause swollen joints and tendons associated with psoriatic arthritis, and when it occurs in the skin, it leads to the red, itchy plaques of psoriasis. How Weight Worsens Symptoms, Affects Treatment 
The effects of weight gain can be felt in people who already have psoriatic arthritis, as extra pounds exacerbate the condition’s symptoms. 
“Excessive weight causes excessive strain and wear and tear through the weight-bearing joints, thereby aggravating symptoms,” such as joint pain, swelling, and stiffness, says Dr. Rosenstein. 
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) , adults who are overweight or obese are diagnosed with arthritis more often than adults with a lower BMI. Nearly 23 percent of overweight and 31 percent of obese U.S. adults report doctor-diagnosed arthritis, as compared with approximately 16 percent of adults who are at or under normal weight. 
Being overweight makes it more difficult to manage the effects of psoriatic arthritis. According to a study published in May 2015 in the journal Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases , obese people with psoriatic arthritis were 47 percent less likely than their normal-weight peers to achieve “minimal disease activity.” The study defined disease activity as a combination of skin flare-ups, enthesitis (inflammation where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone), tender and swollen joints, pain levels, and general functionality for at least a year . Similarly, people who were overweight (with a BMI between 25 and 30) were 34 percent less likely to have minimal disease activity. 
Another weight-related concern is the impact on your treatment’s effectiveness. That’s because excess weight can affect how drugs are processed in the body. As Dr. Ruderman points out, “being overweight may negatively impact the effects of medication, especially biologics,” which target specific parts of the immune system associated with psoriatic disease. Reaping the Benefits of Losing Excess Weight 
The good news: Losing excess weight can help relieve the symptoms and change the course of psoriatic arthritis. In a study published in June 2014 in the journal Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases , researchers found that overweight or obese people with psoriatic arthritis who lost at least 5 percent of their body weight had a higher rate of achieving minimal disease activity after starting treatment. The type of diet used to achieve that weight loss didn’t make a difference — reducing total food and calorie intake was the key. 
Exercise can help not only with weight loss but with preserving muscle mass and functionality as well. Physical activity can also boost emotional health, which is important because depression and anxiety are common among people with psoriatic arthritis. 
Working out may be seem daunting when you have psoriatic arthritis. “If your joints hurt, sometimes it’s a challenge to exercise more,” Ruderman says. “It’s best to focus on things you can do that don’t use joints that are bothering you. If your lower body hurts, work your upper body,” for example. 
Swimming is a good all-around choice because it’s nonimpact, and the water’s natural buoyancy provides a cushion for painful or swollen joints. Other options include yoga, tai chi, or using an elliptical machine or stationary bicycle. Ultimately, “it’s about activity and movement as much as, or more than, exercise,” Ruderman says. posts.title: How Makeup Can Help With Your Psoriasis | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Living with Psoriasis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit We respect your privacy . There are steps you can take to protect your skin if you apply makeup when you have psoriasis. Shutterstock 
Amy Kelly knows how living with psoriasis can take a toll on a person’s activities and social life. “It affected me so much that I wouldn’t go out with my friends,” she says. “When I looked in the mirror, it was all I could see.” 
Kelly was diagnosed with psoriasis when she was 12 years old. “It started off on my scalp, and gradually spread all over my body,” she says. “There’s not one place on my body I don’t have it now.” 
Kelly, 25, who’s from Dublin, Ireland, had a tough time managing her symptoms. She tried various topicals, drugs, and light therapy . She also found techniques to care for her skin and make her psoriasis less obvious. 
“When it’s on your face, you can’t cover it [with clothes], and makeup makes it look so much worse if you don’t have the right products,” she says. After testing different products and methods, Kelly made a YouTube tutorial to help others with psoriasis. 
Here are six tips for using skincare and makeup products to safely cover flares without irritating your skin: 
1. Pamper your skin before applying makeup. Just putting concealer over a psoriasis plaque can make it stand out even more. Kelly says that some of her early attempts at covering her psoriasis made it look like chickenpox. But she’s found ways to keep her skin as calm as possible, making it easier to conceal signs of psoriasis around her eyes and mouth. Kelly uses a cleanser, exfoliant, mask, and moisturizer on her skin before applying any makeup. When it comes to products, she cautions that what works for one person might irritate someone else’s skin. Try first testing out products on a small area of skin not affected by psoriasis. 
2. Keep your skin hydrated. Keeping your skin moisturized can minimize flaking and redness. Kelly uses hydrating cleansers, exfoliators, and foundations. “Use makeup products for dry skin so they're not powdery, as [makeup] will only stick to the psoriasis if they're not for dry skin,” she says. 
3. Blending is key. When using foundation and concealer, don’t just cover up specific spots. Blending in products over the entire face will make your makeup look more natural. Kelly recommends using a brush over your face. Look for products that match your skin tone. 
4. Use cream or gel-based products. These products often have hydrating ingredients, which can minimize flaking and peeling. Powder-based foundations, highlighters, and blushes can stick in the uneven cracks of a psoriasis plaque, making them stand out even more than if you had no makeup on. Liquid and cream-based makeups also usually last longer. 
5. Don’t overdo it. “I can really only wear makeup once a week. Wearing it every day would be too much for my skin, and it would be quite red,” says Kelly. If you’re having a bad flare, applying makeup can make it worse. When her skin is too irritated, “I end up with makeup stuck to the psoriasis, and it looks so much worse,” she says. Makeup is most effective when your psoriasis treatment is working, and your skin is calm. 
6. Makeup isn’t a cure-all. A makeup regimen may help conceal psoriasis, but it can’t make the condition disappear. Some flares might be too severe to cover up, or makeup will be too irritating to your skin. The key is to treat your skin properly, so work closely with your dermatologist to manage the psoriasis. Kelly also stresses the importance of having a healthy attitude. “Don't let it take over your life or your mind,” she says. “I let it do this to me for so long, and it's not worth it. Now I've completely changed my ways of thinking, and that's helped so much.”

posts.title: Exercise and Diabetes: How to Organize Workouts for Better Blood Sugar Control | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Living with Diabetes Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit We respect your privacy . Aerobic and anaerobic exercises are both important for people with diabetes, but some research suggests the order may matter. Anna Bizon/Getty Images 
If you have diabetes, you probably already know that you need to take precautions during exercise to help protect your feet and maintain stable blood sugar levels. But did you know that the type of workout you pick — along with how you organize that workout — could actually affect your blood sugar levels as well? The Benefits of Physical Fitness for Type 2 Diabetes 
“Exercise is a key diabetes self-management strategy, primarily because it can help reduce insulin resistance and lowers blood sugar levels,” says Lynn Grieger, RDN, CDE , a health, food, and fitness coach in Prescott, Arizona, and a medical reviewer for Everyday Health. 
And the way that exercise affects your blood sugar depends on whether that exercise is aerobic or anaerobic, says Christine Mueller, RD , a nutrition specialist at the Adult Diabetes Education Program at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Aerobic exercise uses large muscle groups in a repeated fashion for a sustained period of time, according to the Cleveland Clinic , while anaerobic exercise is intense physical activity of short duration. Examples of aerobic exercise include walking or jogging, and weight lifting falls under anaerobic exercise, Mueller explains. 
“The reason is that we store glucose — what we use for energy — in our muscles and in our liver,” Mueller says. “And when we start doing a more intense exercise, like anaerobic exercise, the body says that it needs the energy right now, and dumps all the stored glucose in the blood.” That temporarily leads to a higher blood sugar. Meanwhile, low-intensity aerobic activities don’t require the same immediate output of energy, and tend to actually lower blood sugar as your body slowly uses up the glucose in your blood. 
Numerous studies have shed further light on the potential ways aerobic and anaerobic exercise may cause blood sugar levels to swing. For example, according to a small study published in November 2012 in The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism , a 10-second sprint can temporarily increase glucose levels in the blood of both people without diabetes as well as those with type 1 diabetes, who saw the greatest effect. 
Meanwhile, an article published in October 2013 in the journal Diabetes Care found that while exercises like walking and cycling can help lower blood glucose levels — regardless of the type of exercise or duration of movement — engaging in a 10-second sprint before or after a moderate activity may prevent low blood sugar levels in those with type 1 diabetes, because the body releases glucose-raising hormones in response to intense activity. 
The American Diabetes Association also notes that the effect of physical activity on your blood sugar will vary, depending on a number of factors, including length of activity. What We Still Don’t Know About 
Grieger says much of the current research has been done on individuals with type 1 diabetes — and we can’t necessarily expect that the results will apply to people with type 2 diabetes. That’s because, while both groups need to keep an eye on their blood sugar, type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease where the pancreas stops producing enough or any insulin, necessitating insulin injections, while type 2 diabetes is a condition marked by insulin resistance, where the body continues to produce insulin for many years, but that insulin isn’t working effectively, Grieger explains. 
Another caveat? Many people call running or swimming aerobic exercise, but if they’re working out at a high intensity, that can actually make these exercises anaerobic, she says — meaning there isn’t such a clear dividing line between activities. 
“What we do know is that the fuel for anaerobic exercise is glucose, and the fuel for aerobic exercise is more fat and less glucose used for fuel,” she explains. And, some people with diabetes — especially people whose bodies no longer produce insulin — may find that anaerobic exercise increases blood sugar levels, because the liver is stimulated to release more glucose, she says. 
But overall, exercise in general — aerobic or anaerobic — tends to make your body more sensitive to insulin , Mueller adds, which is more good news for your blood sugar control. How to Structure Your Workouts to Improve Blood Sugar Control 
So what’s the best way to structure your workouts to keep blood sugar levels within a safe range? Try following these tips: 
Aim for a mix of aerobic and anaerobic exercise. Overall, Grieger notes, combining both aerobic and anaerobic exercise in your workout may give you the best blood sugar control. Try a fitness trail with exercise equipment or stations where you do push-ups, lunges, and other strength-training exercises, she says. Or try a boot camp class, or an interval-style workout that includes 20 seconds of hard work, followed by 10 seconds of rest, repeated 4 to 8 times, she says. Add additional reps as needed, increasing the rest period as you go. 
Tailor your workout to your goals. Often, body builders do strength exercises first, followed by aerobic exercise, because their focus is on building strength, Grieger says. Runners, by contrast, often do the opposite, since they’re focused on endurance. 
You can tailor your workout to your goals, she says, though Grieger recommends that people with type 2 diabetes focus especially on aerobic exercise first, because of its cardiovascular benefits. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) , adults with type 2 diabetes are about two times as likely to die of heart disease as those people without diabetes. 
Mueller notes that if you do strength-training or anaerobic exercise first, followed by lower-intensity aerobic exercise, you may find that you’re able to help normalize your blood sugar levels and prevent them from spiking too high, since the spike from the anaerobic activity would be counteracted by the aerobic activity that follows. 
Keep track of your blood sugar, no matter what workout you’re doing. Make sure your blood sugar doesn’t dip below 100 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dl) before a workout, according to the Mayo Clinic . 
“When blood sugar levels fall, there isn’t enough energy for the body to continue functioning optimally,” Grieger explains. “People with hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) can experience mental confusion, headaches, dizziness, shaking, and clumsiness, and feel very tired. If blood sugar levels continue to fall, a person with diabetes can even pass out.” 
And make sure that you pay attention to how your body reacts to different types of exercise. “The best way for people with diabetes to discover how exercise order affects their blood sugar levels is to test their blood sugar before starting exercise and after finishing exercise, and to note if there are differences,” Grieger says. 
Finally, make sure that you don’t exercise if your blood sugar is already very high, such as more than 250 mg/dL, according to the Mayo Clinic. Then, you’re putting yourself at risk of high blood sugar levels that could lead to a dangerous state called diabetic ketoacidosis , where your body won’t have enough insulin available or may not use it correctly in order to use sugar for energy, and will go into “starvation mode,” and start using fat for energy instead, which produces ketones, she explains. 
Most important, be sure to have fun. “Often, people get so caught up in the ‘rules’ around exercise that they don’t exercise at all,” Grieger says. “It’s important to begin doing something and gradually make exercise a fun part of your day rather than to not do anything at all.” Last Updated:

thread.title: Weight Gain After Quitting Smoking: How One Woman With Diabetes Is Coping | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Weight Gain After Quitting Smoking: How One Woman With Diabetes Is Coping | Everyday Health

posts.author: Gianetta Palmer
posts.title: Weight Gain After Quitting Smoking: How One Woman With Diabetes Is Coping | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Living with Diabetes Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit Quitting smoking not only leads to physical changes — it may alter your perspective, too. Getty Images 
“Do you smoke?” asked the medical assistant in the pulmonologist's office who was taking down my medical history. 
“Yes,” I replied, watching as she checked the “yes” box on the paper on her clipboard. 
She made a “tsk tsk” noise between her teeth — almost like the sound I use to call my cats — and said, “You know, smoking isn’t good for you since you have diabetes.” 
I knew. 
“The doctor will be in with you shortly,” replied the medical assistant, as she walked out of the office. Why I Started Smoking in the First Place 
My endocrinologist sent me to see a pulmonologist because I had a case of bronchitis that left me perpetually wheezing whenever I walked a mere few steps. 
I had started smoking when I was around 20 years old, when in between classes at community college several of my friends played cards together over cigarettes. I smoked just to fit in. My dad smoked, too, and we even raised tobacco on the family farm growing up in southern Ohio. I smoked at least a pack, sometimes more, every day: Lighting up was the first thing I did in the morning and the last thing I did at night. 
I liked to smoke — specifically the social aspect of it. But now, I could barely breathe, and it was interfering with my job — I was out of the office and sick more often, and the constant hacking and coughing left those people around me wanting to be elsewhere. 
The aforementioned appointment with the endocrinologist was the ultimate reality check. A Renewed Motivation to Try to Quit Smoking 
“How long have you been smoking?” the doctor asked. 
“Almost 20 years,” I replied. 
“How long have you had type 2 diabetes ?” she countered. 
“About 10 years.” 
Again, I thought I heard that same “tsk tsk” noise, as the doctor proceeded to put me through a battery of tests. They involved checking how long I could hold my breath and how fast I could blow out my breath, as well as a walk around the office to see how winded I would become. 
I sat in a chair, catching my breath while the results were calculated, and soon the doctor returned to the room. 
“You HAVE to stop smoking,” she practically yelled. “Otherwise, in a couple of years, you’re going to be carrying around an oxygen tank.” 
I think she saw the alarm on my face, but she continued with something like: “Diabetes and smoking have one common denominator. Over time, both cause constriction of the nerves, thus cutting off blood flow, which in turn leads to nerve damage. You have to stop smoking.” 
And I did. 
I ended up at the ER several months later, unable to breathe because of another bout of bronchitis. The doctor there echoed what my previous doctor said and went one step further by writing me a prescription for Chantix (varenicline) . “I’ve heard good things about this drug,” he said. “Give it a shot.” 
I smoked my last cigarette at age 40, on Thanksgiving night 2006, and went into work the next day. My coworkers at the U.S. Postal Service cheered me on, and those who smoked stayed away from me so I wouldn’t be tempted by the smell. 
I stepped on the large scale behind the office to record my weight because I knew a side effect of quitting was weight gain . It wasn’t easy, but I was determined this time, and the days flew by, as weeks turned into months. I did feel better and I could certainly breathe better, but I noticed my clothes were getting tight. After Quitting Smoking, Gaining Breath — and Weight 
On the first anniversary of quitting smoking, I commented to my mother that I needed to go shopping because my pants no longer fit. On the second anniversary, I held my breath when I stepped on the scale at the doctor’s office, because I had gone up another two shirt and pant sizes. The same medical assistant from two years prior wrote the number down on my chart, smiled and walked out the door. 
The doctor entered the room and looked over my charts — I’d had the same tests run as before and she began to speak. “First of all, your numbers look really good — your breathing is definitely better, but my assistant said you were very winded during the walk around the office. Why is that?” she asked. 
“I’ve gained some weight,” I said. 
“According to my records, you’ve gained 83 pounds. Are you watching what you’re eating?” the doctor asked. 
All I could think of was 83 pounds. Had I really gained that much weight? “I’m trying to watch my diet, but I think I might be eating too much.” I left the office armed with a slew of new pamphlets on low-calorie eating plans and headed home. Finding Solutions to Weight Gain After Kicking the Habit 
I was unhappy. I felt that the weight gain had all but negated any benefits of quitting smoking . As my weight increased, so did my need for insulin . Honestly, the only part of “watching what I was eating” I was actually doing was watching the food as I shoveled it into my mouth. I was out of control. If I wanted doughnuts, I ate them and compensated by increasing my insulin dosage at mealtime. I wasn’t always successful, and my A1C went up. 
While I know smoking increases the risk of diabetes complications and other life-threatening comorbidities, like heart disease , I can’t help but feel that by replacing one bad habit (smoking) with another (overeating), I haven’t done my body any good. After all, weight gain only increases insulin resistance , the hallmark of diabetes, and, like smoking, makes the diabetes harder to control. 
Now 10 years have passed, and I am still smoke-free. I have gained nearly 100 pounds total in my journey, but gradually, over time, I have lost 30 of them by following Weight Watchers and portion control. It’s a slow process, but I’m making progress. Looking Ahead to More Benefits of Quitting Smoking 
Every day poses a challenge to balance what I eat, get the appropriate amount of exercise, and hope my glucose levels stay where they belong. I’m no longer winded when I take the walk around the medical complex, and I no longer have a desire to smoke. In fact, I can’t even stand the smell of a cigarette now. 
One of the things I did at my five-year anniversary was take a trip overseas with my mother with the money saved from not having to buy a carton of cigarettes every week. I’ve saved thousands of dollars. 
I’m still bummed about the extra weight, but I try and let it go. I’m doing the best I can, and, as my doctor likes to joke, “You may be a few pounds overweight, but at least you don’t smoke.” 
She’s right. I can lose the weight, and I will, because since I quit smoking, I’ve probably added 10 or more years to my life. 
And I definitely want to be around to take many more trips. Last Updated:

posts.title: Is It Lung Cancer? What Tests Will I Get? | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Everyday Health Lung Cancer Is It Lung Cancer? What Tests Will I Get? If you have lung cancer, you’ll likely undergo a range of scans and other tests to confirm your diagnosis. Here’s what you can expect. Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit Once lung cancer is suspected, an array of tests can pinpoint how advanced it is. Johnny Greig/iStock.com 
Early screening for high-risk individuals — such as longtime smokers — nagging coughs, and random X-rays are often the beginning of the "maybe it’s lung cancer" journey. But what happens after that? 
More testing. These additional tests are designed to help your doctor pinpoint the type of lung cancer you have, such as small cell or non–small cell; its stage, or how large it is and whether and to what other areas it may have spread; and its molecular profile, all of which dictate treatment. 
Here’s what you can expect: 
PET Scan Short for positron emission tomography, PET scans track cancer cells that may be lurking and growing in other areas beyond the original location. For the test, a small amount of radioactive sugar is injected into a vein. The sugar then collects in tissues and organs that are very active and rely on sugar to provide energy, such as very active organs (the heart and brain), and fast growing tissues, such as tumors. 
Next, you get a full-body scan in a large machine that picks up the radioactive sugar in spots where cancer cells might be. This information shows up via 3D images your doctor can see. “PET scans are one of the ways we stage the disease, because they’re good at finding cancer that’s spread to bone, the liver, and the adrenal glands, which are areas lung cancer tends to go,” says Gaetane Michaud, MD , associate professor of pulmonary medicine and cardiothoracic surgery at NYU Langone Health’s Perlmutter Cancer Center in New York City. 
Though PET scans can’t see every cancer cell, and often miss small tumors, they help see if there are large tumors that have already developed in other parts of the body. 
Brain MRI You may get an MRI, or magnetic resonance imaging, of your brain because that organ is one place lung cancer may spread. The brain takes up sugar at a speed similar to tumors, so your brain always “lights up” on a PET scan, limiting how useful PET scans are at detecting spread to the brain, says Dr. Michaud. An MRI uses magnetic fields , rather than X-rays, to produce detailed pictures of the body. For the test, you receive an injection of a contrast medium that helps improve the images obtained in the scanner. 
Biopsies Imaging may tell you the size of the cancer, and where it may have spread. But it’s not good enough for final diagnosis and staging. For that, you’ll need a biopsy, in which your doctor will take a sample of the cancerous tissue from your lung or other organs to which the cancer may have spread. 
The aim of a biopsy, says Michaud, is to obtain a large enough tissue sample from the most-affected area. That gives doctors the best chance to make the most accurate diagnosis and staging as possible, she says. Even if you have had a biopsy of the tumor in the lung, if the PET scan or MRI shows there is a suspicious mass elsewhere in the body, you may also need this to be biopsied to see if it is cancer that has spread, or just a benign lesion. 
Cancer that has spread outside the lung is treated much differently from cancer located only in the lung, so these additional biopsies are necessary to dictate the treatment that will be recommended. 
There are several types of biopsies: 
Needle Biopsy or Needle Aspiration This involves getting a tissue sample via a needle inserted into the body through the skin, which is numbed with a local anesthetic. The placement of the needle is guided by imaging tests, such as ultrasound, CT (computerized tomography), or MRI. The doctor removes a small bit of tissue, which is sent to a lab for analysis. The whole test takes up to an hour. 
Endobronchial Ultrasound (EBUS) In this test, an ultrasound probe on the tip of a scope is sent down through the windpipe into the main branches of the lungs. “The ultrasound allows us to see structures around these branches, such as lymph nodes, where cancer may have spread,” says Michaud. EBUS allows your doctor to get deeper into portions of the lung that aren’t accessible via a needle biopsy. 
An EBUS can also be used to obtain a tissue sample from the lungs or lymph nodes, which can then be sent to a lab. These can tell your doctor whether a tumor in your lung has spread to the lymph nodes — this is also information that will affect the type of therapy the doctors recommend. 
Electromagnetic Navigation This, says Michaud, is “like a GPS for your lung. We input the results of a CT scan [of the lungs] into a computer program and tell it what area we need to reach, and the computer gives us a pathway out to that area, just like the GPS in your car.” Once at the precise spot, a tissue sample is taken. The advantage of using electromagnetic navigation is that it allows doctors to reach a precise spot and avoid some of the risks of biopsy through the skin, such as a collapsed lung. Waiting for Results 
How long it takes to find out the results of tests varies widely, both by where you get tested — some institutions do their own lab testing; others have to send out samples — and what type of test you have, says Michaud. The results for imaging tests may be read within hours at some centers or take between three to five days at others. Other tests, such as biopsies, can take longer. Last Updated:

thread.title: Could Skipping Breakfast Feed Heart Disease? | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Could Skipping Breakfast Feed Heart Disease? | Everyday Health

posts.author: Amy Norton
posts.title: Could Skipping Breakfast Feed Heart Disease? | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Could Skipping Breakfast Feed Heart Disease? Forgoing morning meal may reduce cardiac health and boost odds for diabetes, study suggests. Sign Up for Our Heart Health Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Breakfast fans are less likely to be obese, have diabetes, or heart disease. Thinkstock 
Middle-aged adults who routinely skip breakfast are more likely to have clogged heart arteries than those who enjoy a big morning meal, a new study finds. 
The findings are the latest to link breakfast to better heart health . 
They suggest that people who eat breakfast -- especially a hearty one -- are less likely to harbor plaques in their arteries. 
Plaques are deposits of fat, calcium and other substances that can build up in arteries, causing them to harden and narrow -- a condition called atherosclerosis. Atherosclerosis can lead to heart attacks, strokes and other complications. 
The new study does not prove that skipping breakfast directly harms people's arteries. 
"It's not that you skip breakfast, you get plaques," said senior researcher Jose Penalvo, of Tufts University's Friedman School of Nutrition Science and Policy in Boston. 
But, he said, there are several reasons that forgoing the morning meal could contribute to the risk of atherosclerosis. 
For many people, skipping breakfast is part of a "cluster" of bad habits, said Penalvo. These people tend to eat out a lot, and opt for nutritionally dubious convenience foods, for instance. 
On top of that, Penalvo said, skipping breakfast may have negative effects on appetite-regulating hormones, blood sugar and insulin (a hormone that regulates blood sugar). 
Prior studies have shown that breakfast fans are less likely to be obese or have diabetes or heart disease . 
But the current study actually used objective tests, Penalvo said. The researchers used ultrasound to screen middle-aged adults for "subclinical" atherosclerosis -- early plaque buildup that is not causing any symptoms. 
RELATED: Surprising Physical Signs of Heart Disease 
The study included more than 4,000 adults ages 40 to 54 from Spain. Three percent were chronic breakfast-skippers, while 27 percent regularly had a big breakfast. That meant they ate more than 20 percent of their daily calories at their morning meal. 
Most people -- 70 percent -- ate a relatively low-calorie breakfast. 
It turned out that those three groups also differed in their odds of subclinical atherosclerosis. 
Nearly 75 percent of breakfast-skippers showed such plaque buildup . That compared with 57 percent of people who ate a big breakfast, and 64 percent of those who favored a light one. 
Breakfast fans were healthier in many ways, the study found. They generally ate more fruits and vegetables, seafood and lean meat, for instance. They were also less likely to be obese or have high blood pressure, diabetes or unhealthy cholesterol levels. 
But even with all those factors weighed, breakfast-skipping, itself, was still tied to a higher risk of atherosclerosis. 
Kim Larson is a registered dietitian and a spokesperson for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics. 
She said the findings are important, in part, because many adults -- around 30 percent -- routinely skip breakfast. 
And some people, she noted, purposely cut out breakfast when they're trying to lose weight. 
That's a bad idea, Larson explained, because of the effects on appetite and eating habits the rest of the day. 
"People who skip breakfast generally make up for it later in the day," said Larson, who wasn't involved in the study. In the end, she said, they typically down more calories over the course of the day, versus people who eat breakfast. 
The current study did not dig into the nutritional quality of people's breakfast choices. But when it comes to preventing disease, Larson said, "quality matters." 
A bagel and coffee is "better than nothing," she noted. However, Larson recommended that breakfast include a healthy mix of protein, carbohydrates and fat. 
She acknowledged that time is an obstacle. Many people are rushed in the morning and end up eating a muffin in the car. 
But breakfast does not need to be extravagant to be healthy, Larson said. Some of her suggestions: oatmeal with nuts and fruit; whole-grain toast with nut butter; granola mixed with yogurt and fruit; and apple slices with peanut butter. 
Penalvo encouraged people to look at it this way: Eating a healthy breakfast is actually an enjoyable way to potentially curb your heart disease risk. 
"This is a really positive message," he said. 
Of course, breakfast is not a stand-alone solution. Penalvo said it should be part of a generally healthy diet and other good habits such as regular exercise. 
The findings were published Oct. 2 in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology . Last Updated:10/3/2017 Copyright @ 2017 HealthDay . All rights reserved. This site complies with the HONcode standard for trustworthy health information: verify here . × Advertising Notice

thread.title: Nerve Damage Can Be Long-Lasting After Chemo for Early Stage Breast Cancer | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Nerve Damage Can Be Long-Lasting After Chemo for Early Stage Breast Cancer | Everyday Health

posts.author: Don Rauf
posts.title: Nerve Damage Can Be Long-Lasting After Chemo for Early Stage Breast Cancer | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter For some women, nerve damage can be long-lasting. Barry Diomede/Alamy 
A chemotherapy drug commonly used to treat early-stage breast cancer may leave patients with unpleasant side effects, and should be monitored carefully, according to a study published in August 2017 in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute . 
The drug, Taxotere (docetaxel) , is part of a class of drugs known as taxanes, which also include Taxol (paclitaxel ). 
While these medications have been known to increase the risk of neuropathy (damage to the nerves), the new research has found that these symptoms may last for years. 
Scientists reviewed data on 1,512 people with early-stage breast cancer who received adjuvant chemotherapy. This type of treatment is used to prevent recurrence after primary treatments such as surgery or radiation. The study found that more than 40 percent reported numbness and tingling in their hands and feet after two years of a regimen involving docetaxel. 
One out of 10 patients characterized their neuropathy symptoms as severe. "For those who rated the severity as 'very much,' the quality of life score was almost 20 points lower compared with those with no bother," says the study’s senior author, Patricia Ganz, MD , the director of cancer prevention and control research at the Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center at the University of California in Los Angeles. 
"We are hoping that oncologists will take note of the risk for long-term neuropathy, especially in older and heavier women," says Dr. Ganz. "Older and heavier women are more likely to have a risk for diabetes, which can also cause neuropathy," says Ganz. 
Participants in the recent study received one of three therapies with Taxotere — Taxotere with Adriamycin (doxorubicin) at the same time; Taxotere with Adriamycin and Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide) at the same time (ACT), or Adriamycin and Cytoxan taken at the same time followed by the Taxotere (AC→T). 
Those in the last group received the highest doses of the taxane. The first group, who took just Adriamycin and Taxotere, had slightly worse results in terms of survival compared with the other two. The ACT group, taking the three treatments at once, had a survival rate almost equal to those in the last group, who took the follow-up Taxotere, but it also had significantly less neuropathy. 
"We hope that oncologists might consider the alternative treatment with ACT if there is concern for persistent neuropathy," says Ganz. 
Ganz suggests that oncologists weigh the risk of persistent neuropathy against the treatment choice to give a taxane-based drug or not, as well as the dose to be given. Other taxanes, such as Taxol (paclitaxel), which is often given weekly instead of every three weeks, may be a better alternative for some patients. 
Alternatives to a taxane include taking just AC (Adriamycin and Cytoxan) or FEC. FEC is Adrucil (5-fluorouracil or 5-FU) , Ellence (epirubicin) , and Cytoxan. "These are the regimens that were commonly used before the taxanes were introduced," says Ganz. Patients Need to Be Better Informed 
Ganz said that breast cancer patients may not anticipate having these kinds of side effects from chemotherapy. 
"Our current research shows that oncologists spend a lot of time informing patients about the acute effects of chemotherapy (nausea, vomiting, fatigue, hair loss, mouth sores, low blood counts) and very serious or rare late effects such as leukemia or heart injury," says Ganz. "However, they rarely discuss the persistent or lingering effects of the chemotherapy treatment and how long they last and whether they are likely to go away." 
Falls, disability, and cognitive difficulties may also increase among these patients because of the toxicity to their nerves. 
Charles Loprinzi, MD , a professor of oncology at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, agrees that chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy is a major long-term problem for a substantial population of patients. 
Dr. Loprinzi says that guidelines from the American Society of Clinical Oncology may have to be updated to reflect these study results. "The guidelines may need more information about how you educate patients about the degree of the problem," he says. "Some patients do not want to stop early; they want to tough it out, and they say it's not that bad and they can put up with it. I suspect that they don't really understand how bad it can be for a long time." What Can Be Done When Neuropathy Symptoms Appear 
Loprinzi says that when his patients get significant neuropathy or get it at a faster rate than expected, he often stops any taxane-based treatment. 
Although there is no highly effective treatment for this nerve damage, there are multiple medications that can offer some relief. Loprinzi says that duloxetine is "the best drug we have at this time to treat established neuropathy." He notes, however, that it doesn't resolve the problem completely and has some side effects itself. 
There are some pilot studies indicating that cryotherapy (using ice or other very cold substances) may also be helpful, according to Loprinzi. Further research results should be available in 2018. Last Updated:

thread.title: Americans More Open About Mental Health Issues, But Stigma Lingers | Everyday Health

posts.author: Amy Norton
posts.title: Americans More Open About Mental Health Issues, But Stigma Lingers | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Americans More Open About Mental Health Issues, But Stigma Lingers Poll found many thought 'personal failings' were part of the cause of some conditions. Sign Up for Our Mental Health & Mood Disorders Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit We respect your privacy . Recognizing when you have symptoms, and speaking up about it, are the first steps toward treatment and recovery. Getty Images 
Americans may be more willing to talk about mental health issues these days, but misperceptions and stigmas persist, a new survey finds. 
The survey, of more than 3,000 U.S. adults, found that 70 percent said they feel people are more open to discussing mental health compared with a decade ago. 
Most respondents also said they'd want to help a family member or friend struggling with depression or other mental health conditions. 
On the other hand, age-old misperceptions were still common. Many people, for example, thought that mental health disorders were at least partially driven by "personal failings." 
"That's certainly disappointing," said Dr. Don Mordecai, director of mental health and addiction medicine services at Kaiser Permanente, in Oakland, Calif., which commissioned the poll. 
"These are true brain conditions," Mordecai said, "and we have to get away from the blaming." 
In reality, he explained, mental health disorders are rooted in factors like genetics, traumatic experiences and imbalances in brain chemicals. 
RELATED: Mental Health Myths Abound in the U.S. 
Dr. Jeffrey Borenstein, a psychiatrist who was not involved in the survey, agreed. 
"Psychiatric conditions are not moral weaknesses or character flaws," said Borenstein, president of the New York City-based Brain & Behavior Research Foundation. 
Borenstein said he was surprised by how many survey respondents mistakenly believed that character was involved. Over 60 percent thought that personal weaknesses were at least partly responsible for depression , for example. 
"We clearly have a long way to go in educating the public," Borenstein said. "These conditions are equal to any other medical condition. In this case, the organ affected is the brain." 
The poll, conducted online in August, included a nationally representative sample of just over 3,000 U.S. adults. 
When asked about the national climate around mental health, 70 percent said they thought Americans were now more open to discussing it. 
People also appeared willing to talk about their own struggles. Nearly 40 percent said they'd faced a mental health "issue" at some point, and nearly all of those people -- 92 percent -- had sought some kind of help. 
In another positive finding, 70 percent of respondents said they would be comfortable offering support if someone they knew had a mental health condition. 
But the poll also uncovered inconsistencies. 
Three-quarters of respondents felt at least somewhat informed about mental health conditions, while a similar percentage said the disorders should be treated no differently from physical health problems. 
Yet they also thought personal character was a factor in many mental health conditions. Fully 80 percent thought that was true of people with alcohol or drug addiction . 
And a significant number thought "most people" with mental health disorders can get better on their own. That included one-quarter of millennials, Mordecai pointed out -- which is concerning. 
"You wouldn't walk around with a broken leg, thinking, 'I'll just heal this myself,'" he said. 
In another concerning finding, more than half of respondents said they thought a family member or friend was silently struggling with a mental health condition -- out of "fear of stigma" or shame. 
In those cases, Borenstein said, people can try to be proactive -- telling their friend that they are concerned and ready to offer help if it's wanted, for example. 
Mordecai pointed to one of the bright spots in the survey: "If you're dealing with a mental health issue, these results show that there are people around you who stand willing to help," he said. 
Recognizing when you have symptoms, and speaking up about it, are the first steps toward treatment and recovery, Mordecai said. 
"We have effective treatments," he stressed -- from "talk therapy" to medications. 
Borenstein agreed. "These are conditions that no one should be ashamed of," he said. "It's very important that people seek help, or encourage others to seek help when they need it." thread.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis Medications Don't Increase Risk of Lymphomas | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Rheumatoid Arthritis Medications Don't Increase Risk of Lymphomas | Everyday Health

posts.author: Joseph Bennington-Castro
posts.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis Medications Don't Increase Risk of Lymphomas | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Rheumatoid Arthritis Medications Don't Increase Risk of Lymphomas Disease-modifying RA medications don't increase lymphoma risk, but uncontrolled inflammation does. Medically Reviewed by Alexa Meara, MD Don't Miss This Sign Up for Our Living with Rheumatoid Arthritis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter TNF blockers don't increase or decrease the risk of lymphoma subtypes, says new research. Martin Shields/Alamy; Getty Images 
For some time, rheumatoid arthritis (RA) has been linked to lymphoma. Research has long shown that people with rheumatoid arthritis have an increased risk for lymphomas (cancer of the lymph nodes) compared with the general population, though scientists have debated whether certain medications may be partly to blame. RA Medication Benefits May Outweigh Risks 
But a new study shows that the risk of lymphoma in people with RA is dependent on the disease itself and not on the RA treatment, suggesting the benefits of the RA medications outweigh the risks, researchers said. 
For the study, published in August 2017 in the journal Annals of Rheumatic Diseases , scientists analyzed data from 12 European rheumatology registers from nine countries, which recorded medication usage and lymphoma occurrence across registered RA patients. Among 124,997 of those with RA, 533 people had lymphomas, the research showed. 
The team compared these figures to data from a European cancer register-based project called HAEMACARE, which covers approximately 30 percent of the European population. RA Treatment Type May Not Affect Lymphoma Risk 
The researchers found that the distribution of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL), B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (BNHL), and T-cell NHL in people with RA was roughly the same as the general population. B-cells and T-cells are types of immune system lymphocytes (subtypes of white blood cells) that fight infections. These findings were true regardless of whether the RA patients took first-line medications such as tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (anti-TNF) which are a common type of drug for RA treatment, also known as TNF inhibitors or TNF blockers. 
"It is very important to note that the treatment of RA does not alter the subtype distribution of lymphomas and that there is no increased risk in TNF inhibitor-treated patients," says a corresponding author of the study, Anne Regierer, MD , of the German Rheumatism Research Center Berlin in Germany. "This means [that] RA itself is responsible for the higher lymphoma risk and not the treatment." Health Risks That People With RA Face 
Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disease in which the immune system attacks the lining of the joints. 
People with RA have an increased risk of various other health issues. For instance, they often also have cardiovascular disease or other heart-related issues , such as heart attack, stroke, congestive heart failure, and peripheral vascular disease, as well as an increased risk of infections ( tuberculosis , in particular). 
Left untreated, RA could lead to various inflammation-related complications that affect other parts of the body , such as the eyes, lungs, and blood vessels. Inflammation May Be the Common Denominator 
Research also shows that the overall incidence of lymphomas in RA patients is nearly double that of the general population, Dr. Regierer and her colleagues report in their study. In particular, people with RA are especially susceptible to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), the most common type of aggressive B-cell lymphomas. 
The link between RA and lymphomas likely has to do with chronic inflammation , rather than TNF inhibitors, Regierer says. 
"It can be speculated that chronic inflammation … can interfere with the maturing B-cells and hence contribute to the malignant transformation and finally lead to lymphoma," she explains. "This hypothesis is strengthened by the fact that the most common subtype of lymphoma in RA patients are diffuse large B-cell NHL, a lymphoma subtype arising from rather mature B-cells." 
Yet, small studies have suggested that certain RA medications may also alter people's risk of getting certain lymphoma subtypes. RA Medications Vindicated? 
Biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, or bDMARDs, are usually the first-line treatment for people with aggressive RA. These drugs, which include TNF inhibitors, suppress the body's overactive immune system or inflammatory processes, ultimately slowing or altering the progression of RA. 
While often effective, these medications may cause various side effects , such as liver damage, lung damage, and increased risk of infections. 
Recent research hints that certain lymphoma subtypes in RA patients may also be associated with certain therapies, such as hepatosplenic T-cell lymphomas with TNFi. Evolving Data On TNF Inhibitors 
Past research suggested a link between TNF inhibitors and lymphoma, but the new study found that TNF inhibitor usage doesn't affect the lymphoma subtype distribution among RA patients — that is, the drugs don't reduce the risk for some subtypes while increasing the risk for others. "This is important because lymphoma is a very heterogeneous group of diseases with totally different survival rates," Regierer says, adding that certain subtypes such as HL have a five-year overall survival rate of almost 80 percent, compared with certain T-cell NHL that have a survival rate of less than 40 percent. Bottom Line: Control Inflammation 
The research ultimately highlights the need for RA patients to get their inflammation under control. Regierer says: "The chronic activation of the immune system needs to be controlled in order to lower morbidity and also mortality in RA and other chronic inflammatory diseases." Last Updated:

thread.title: Breast Cancer's Decline May Have Saved 322,000 Lives | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Breast Cancer's Decline May Have Saved 322,000 Lives | Everyday Health

posts.author: Mary Elizabeth Dallas
posts.title: Breast Cancer's Decline May Have Saved 322,000 Lives | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Breast Cancer's Decline May Have Saved 322,000 Lives But advances in care may not have helped black women as much as whites, report finds. Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit Excluding skin cancers, breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death among American women. Getty Images 
New research finds the number of American women who've lost their lives to breast cancer has fallen precipitously in the past 25 years, with more than 322,000 lives saved in that time. 
Overall, advances in care have led to a 39 percent drop in breast cancer deaths of between 1989 and 2015, according to new research from the American Cancer Society (ACS). 
One specialist who works with breast cancer patients daily was heartened by the news. 
"Early screening and better treatments are finally starting to pay off with better outcomes," said Dr. Stephanie Bernik, chief of surgical oncology at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. 
However, the ACS was quick to point out that not every segment of Americans benefited equally. Despite some closure of the racial "gap" in breast cancer survival, black women are still more likely to die of the disease than their white peers, the study found. 
Even though the rate of breast cancer diagnosis was slightly lower among black women than whites between 2010 and 2014, over about the same time period, black breast cancer patients were still 42 percent more likely to die of the disease than their white peers. 
According to breast cancer specialist Dr. Cynara Coomer, that's probably due to a combination of factors. Black patients are more prone to be affected by aggressive, tough-to-treat breast tumors, she noted. But they also often lack access to the targeted treatments that can best fight these tumors. 
RELATED: Breast Cancer Radiation 'Less Scary' Than Thought 
So, when it comes to surviving breast cancer , "there remains a disparity between black women and white women across the country," said Coomer, who directs the Florina Rusi-Marke Comprehensive Breast Center at Staten Island University Hospital in New York City. 
The vast majority of breast cancers are diagnosed among women aged 50 and older, the ACS found, and older women account for most deaths from the disease as well. 
Still, race seemed to play a role here, as well. The median age of diagnosis for women overall in the United States is 62, but the disease tends to strike black women at a younger age, the report showed. 
The median age for breast cancer deaths is 68, but black patients died younger -- at 62, on average. 
All of this means that, overall, breast cancer kills more black women than white women in the United States. 
There was reason to hope, however, because this health disparity may be stabilizing in some parts of the country, the ACS said. For example, breast cancer death rates among black women ranged from 22 percent in Nevada to 66 percent in Louisiana, the report found. 
But in seven states the researchers saw no significant difference in death rates between black and white patients -- showing that the racial gap can be closed. 
While genetics and differences in overall health play a big role in the survival gap between blacks and whites, so do "social and structural factors," said Carol DeSantis, of the ACS's surveillance and health services research branch. 
"Increasing access to health care to low-income populations" might shrink this racial gap even further across the country, she explained. 
Coomer agreed, saying that black women with aggressive tumors, in particular, "would be better served with health care teams or centers that provide comprehensive breast treatment ." 
According to Bernik, progress is being made. 
"The fact that we are finally seeing a close in the gap between our excellent outcomes between black and white women is also encouraging," she said, "especially since black women are more likely to be diagnosed with the more aggressive triple-negative breast cancers." 
Excluding skin cancers, breast cancer is the second leading cause of cancer death among American women, trailing only lung cancer. It's estimated that 252,710 women will be diagnosed with breast cancer in 2017 and 40,610 will die from the disease. 
The research was published Oct. 3 in CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians and Breast Cancer Facts & Figures . Last Updated:

thread.title: Moving Just 1 Hour a Week May Curb Depression Risk | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Moving Just 1 Hour a Week May Curb Depression Risk | Everyday Health

posts.author: Alan Mozes
posts.title: Moving Just 1 Hour a Week May Curb Depression Risk | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Moving Just 1 Hour a Week May Curb Depression Risk Intensity of exercise didn't matter, and benefit leveled off after 2 hours of activity, study finds. Sign Up for Our Mental Health & Mood Disorders Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter We respect your privacy . People who engage in just an hour of exercise per week have a lower risk of developing depression. Getty Images 
Career couch potatoes, take heart: Just one hour a week of any kind of exercise may lower your long-term risk for depression, new research suggests. 
The finding comes from a fresh analysis of a Norwegian survey that tracked exercise habits, along with depression and anxiety risk, among nearly 34,000 adults. 
After a closer look at the data, a team of British, Australian and Norwegian analysts determined that people who engage in just an hour of exercise per week -- regardless of intensity level -- face a 44 percent lower risk for developing depression over the course of a decade than those who never exercise at all. 
"The key finding from this study is that doing even a small amount of regular exercise seems to protect adults against future depression," said study author Samuel Harvey. 
"This was not a case of more is better; the vast majority of the mental health benefits of exercise was realized when individuals moved from doing no regular activity to 1 or 2 hours per week," Harvey explained. 
"Also, the mental health benefits were there regardless of the intensity of the physical activity," he added. "There is great evidence that there are many physical health benefits to more regular exercise, but the mental health benefits leveled out after 2 hours." 
RELATED: 7 Common Myths About Depression 
Harvey is an associate professor with the School of Psychiatry at the University of New South Wales, in Sydney, Australia. "The important point here is that any type of physical activity -- even just walking -- had similar levels of mental health benefits," he concluded. 
The original survey was launched between 1984 and 1986. In that timeframe, participants (who were about 45 years old, on average) underwent physical exams, and filled out lifestyle and medical questionnaires. Mental health assessments were also completed. 
The Norwegian pollsters conducted a follow-up survey between 1995 and 1997 among roughly two-thirds of the original participants. 
About 7 percent of those tracked through 1997 had developed depression, while about 9 percent had developed clinical levels of anxiety , the findings showed. 
Exercise did not appear to have any impact on anxiety risk. But investigators found that, regardless of gender or activity intensity, regular exercise lasting at least an hour per week was linked to a lower risk for developing depression over time. 
The study authors calculated that roughly 12 percent of the depression cases might have been prevented if those who had become depressed had previously routinely engaged in one hour of low-intensity activity a week. 
Exercising more than one hour per week did not, however, appear to substantially decrease depression risk even further; the lion's share of the protective impact appeared to max out at the one-hour mark. 
But as to how and why such a minimal amount of regular exercise might help stave off depression, the study team wrote that "the bulk of the observed protective effect remains unexplained." And the study did not prove a cause-and-effect relationship between exercise and lower risk of depression. 
Harvey and his colleagues reported their observations in the Oct. 3 issue of the American Journal of Psychiatry . 
Simon Rego, chief psychologist at Montefiore Medical Center/Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York City, said that "there are probably many mechanisms at play that could explain how this works. But it doesn't have the same effect on anxiety, so we just don't know yet exactly what's happening." 
However, Rego added, "What we do know is that what they've identified is a very low bar of entry. We're talking about just an hour of activity a week. And it doesn't have to be vigorous or intense. You don't need to go out to a spin class or sign up for a running club. This could just be getting people who aren't moving much to just increase their daily walking habit. That's all." 
So, he explained, "while we don't have all the definitive answers yet, this is a very promising finding because this is something many people may find easy to do." Obesity Linked to 13 Types of Cancer Losing weight might lower the risk, researchers say. Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit We respect your privacy . These 13 obesity-related cancers made up about 40 percent of all cancers diagnosed in the United States in 2014. Getty Images 
There's a link between obesity and 40 percent of all the cancers diagnosed in the United States, health officials reported Tuesday. 
That doesn't mean too much weight is causing all these cancer cases, just that there's some kind of still-to-be explained association, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
Still, the study findings suggest that being obese or overweight was associated with cancer cases involving more than 630,000 Americans in 2014, and this includes 13 types of cancer . 
"That obesity and overweight are affecting cancers may be surprising to many Americans. The awareness of some cancers being associated with obesity and overweight is not yet widespread," Dr. Anne Schuchat, CDC deputy director, said during a midday media briefing. 
The 13 cancers include: brain cancer; multiple myeloma ; cancer of the esophagus; postmenopausal breast cancer; cancers of the thyroid, gallbladder, stomach, liver, pancreas, kidney, ovaries, uterus and colon, the researchers said. 
Speaking at the news conference, Dr. Lisa Richardson, director of CDC's Division of Cancer Prevention and Control, said early evidence indicates that losing weight can lower the risk for some cancers. 
According to the new report from the CDC and the U.S. National Cancer Institute, these 13 obesity-related cancers made up about 40 percent of all cancers diagnosed in the United States in 2014. 
RELATED: U.S. Cancer Death Rate Continues to Fall 
Although the rate of new cancer cases has decreased since the 1990s, increases in overweight and obesity-related cancers are likely slowing this progress, the researchers said. 
Of the 630,000 Americans diagnosed with a cancer associated with overweight or obesity in 2014, about two out of three occurred in adults aged 50 to 74, the researchers found. 
Excluding colon cancer, the rate of obesity-related cancer increased by 7 percent between 2005 and 2014. During the same time, rates of non-obesity-related cancers dropped, the findings showed. 
In 2013-2014, about two out of three American adults were overweight or obese, according to the report. 
For the study, researchers analyzed 2014 cancer data from the United States Cancer Statistics report and data from 2005 to 2014. 
Key findings include: Of all cancers, 55 percent in women and 24 percent in men were associated with overweight and obesity. Blacks and whites had higher rates of weight-related cancer than other racial or ethnic groups . Black men and American Indian/Alaska Native men had higher rates of cancer than white men. Cancers linked to obesity increased 7 percent between 2005 and 2014, but colon cancer decreased 23 percent. Screening for colon cancer is most likely the reason for that cancer's continued decline, Schuchat said. Cancers not linked to obesity dropped 13 percent. Except for colon cancer, cancers tied to overweight and obesity increased among those younger than 75. 
The new report was published online Oct. 3 in the CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report . 
Dr. Farhad Islami is strategic director of cancer surveillance research for the American Cancer Society. 
He said it's "important to note that only a fraction of the cancers included in the calculation in this report are actually caused by excess body weight." 
According to Islami, "many are attributable to other known risk factors, like smoking , while for many others, the cause is unknown. Obesity is more strongly associated with some cancers than others." 
The World Cancer Research Fund estimates that "20 percent of all cancers in the United States are caused by a combination of excess body weight, physical inactivity, excess alcohol, and poor nutrition. The American Cancer Society is currently doing its own extensive calculation of the numbers and proportions of cancer cases attributable to excess body weight, the results of which will be published soon," he said. 1 in 5 Have Been Hit By a Medical Error, Survey Shows Just half reported the mistake to their provider. Sign Up for Our Healthy Living Newsletter Thanks for signing up! 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Submit When medical errors occur, they often have lasting impact on the patient's physical and emotional health. Martin Barraud/Getty Images 
One-fifth of American adults have been at the receiving end of a medical error, a new survey finds. 
The nationwide poll included more than 2,500 adults. The survey also found that one in three people said another person whose care they were closely involved with had experienced a medical error . 
Most medical errors were associated with diagnosis and patient-provider communications. Outpatient settings were a common site of medical errors. 
On average, respondents who experienced a medical error identified at least seven different factors that caused the error. Nearly half of those who noted an error told medical staff or other workers at the health care facility about it. 
Most people feel that health care providers have the prime responsibility for patient safety . But survey participants also said that patients and their families have a role, too. 
Still, most people said they didn't worry personally about patient safety, the survey found. 
When medical errors occur, they often have lasting impact on the patient's physical and emotional health , finances, or family relationships. 
The survey was done by the IHI/NPSF Lucian Leape Institute and NORC at the University of Chicago. 
"The survey results show that Americans recognize that patient safety is a critically important, but complex, issue," Dr. Tejal Gandhi, chief clinical and safety officer, IHI, and president of the IHI/NPSF Lucian Leape Institute, said in an organization news release.
