thread.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis: Insist That Your Doctor Monitor Your Bone Mineral Density | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Rheumatoid Arthritis: Insist That Your Doctor Monitor Your Bone Mineral Density | Everyday Health

posts.author: Stacey Colino
posts.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis: Insist That Your Doctor Monitor Your Bone Mineral Density | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Living with Rheumatoid Arthritis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Regular bone density checks will help you keep your bones strong. Getty Images 
It’s no secret that rheumatoid arthritis increases a person’s chances of developing osteoporosis, a disease in which bones become brittle and fragile from low bone mass and bone tissue loss. This in turn increases the risk of fracture. 
Despite these added risks, many people who have rheumatoid arthritis (RA) aren’t being screened for osteoporosis the way they should be. In fact, 33 percent of 11,669 patients with RA didn’t have any screening for osteoporosis over a five-and-a-half-year period, and only half of RA patients who should have been treated with a medication for osteoporosis actually were, according to a study published online in August 2017 in Arthritis Care & Research . Systemic Inflammation Threatens Health of Bones 
The primary reason why people with RA have a higher risk of developing osteoporosis is that RA is an autoimmune disease that involves systemic inflammation . “The inflammation from RA doesn't just affect the joints — it also affects the bones,” says Veena K. Ranganath, MD , an associate clinical professor of medicine in the division of rheumatology at the UCLA David Geffen School of Medicine in Los Angeles. Specifically, a chronic inflammatory state can accelerate bone loss and bone turnover. RA Can Interfere With Fitness Activity Required for Healthy Bones 
On top of that, symptoms such as RA-induced pain, swelling, joint stiffness, and fatigue can cause people with the disease to be less physically active, which also increases the risk of osteoporosis . Normally, engaging in weight-bearing activities provides the signals the body needs to build stronger bones, explains Ashira Blazer, MD , a rheumatologist at New York University's Langone Medical Center in New York City. “Avoiding weight-bearing activities means the body gets fewer of these signals" to increase bone density. Rheumatoid Arthritis Drugs Can Weaken Bones 
In addition, some of the drugs that are used to treat RA can lead to loss of bone density. For example, glucocorticoids (a class of corticosteroids) like prednisone are known to increase the risk of fractures. “If anyone is taking steroids for more than two months, their bone density should be checked, especially if they’re over 65 or if they have risk factors such as a previous fracture or they smoke,” Ranganath says. Doctors Don't Always Screen for Bone Density Problems 
But this screening protocol isn’t being practiced consistently, either. In a study published in September 2015 by the American College of Rheumatology , researchers evaluated 52 patients with rheumatoid arthritis and found that 53 percent of them were not screened appropriately for glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis; the American College of Rheumatology recommends screenings based on patients' risk factors, their score on FRAX (a diagnostic tool used to evaluate bone fracture risk) , and their use of prednisone. This lack of screening was especially true for younger patients and male patients. Medication Side Effects: Ask Your MD About Your Bone Risks 
Since hard-and-fast guidelines for measuring bone density in people with RA don’t exist, the onus may be on you to broach the subject if your doctor doesn’t. This is particularly important if you’ve been taking steroid medications for two months or more. If you have RA, you should also have a candid discussion with your doctor about your other risk factors for osteoporosis . Make Sure You Get Bone Mineral Density Tests 
A simple, painless assessment of your bone mineral density, called a DXA (short for dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry) scan, can be done to check for osteoporosis, especially in the spine and hips. With repeated DXA scans, “you really want to use the same machine you used before for the sake of consistent results,” Ranganath says. “The results are also operator dependent.” What You Can Do to Keep Your Bones Strong 
Once you know your bone mineral density, you can take additional steps to protect it — perhaps by consuming more calcium and vitamin D , getting more physical exercise, avoiding smoking or excessive alcohol consumption, or adjusting your medications. After all, disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and some of the newer biologic drugs have a more positive effect on bone mineral density, Ranganath says. Last Updated:

thread.title: A Man's Health May Rely on Health of His Marriage | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: A Man's Health May Rely on Health of His Marriage | Everyday Health

posts.author: Randy Dotinga
posts.title: A Man's Health May Rely on Health of His Marriage | Everyday Health
posts.text:
A Man's Health May Rely on Health of His Marriage Heart risk factors improve when married life is good, decline when it's not, study finds. Sign Up for Our Men's Health Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter People in healthy relationships are much more healthy than those who are single. Getty Images 
As marriage ebbs and flows, so might the health of your heart, at least for men. 
A new British study of married fathers found real -- if small -- effects on such cardiovascular risk factors as cholesterol levels , body weight and blood pressure that corresponded to improvement or deterioration in the men's marriages. 
Those whose marriages seemed to be improving fared better, while the reverse was true for men in worsening marriages. 
"An apparent link between marriage and health is a consistent finding across many studies, going back as far as 1912," said Dr. Ian Bennett-Britton. He's the study's lead author and a research fellow at the University of Bristol in England. 
"What's not been clear is whether this is simply a reflection of healthier and wealthier people getting married or a true protective effect of the marriage itself," he added. 
Marriage researcher Dr. Rahul Potluri, a cardiologist with Aston University in Birmingham, England, said that "the evidence so far suggests that married couples and perhaps happier couples are more inclined to look after each other, which may have a direct impact on cardiovascular risk factors and cardiovascular disease ." 
For the new study, Bennett-Britton and his colleagues surveyed 620 married fathers about their relationships, and then tracked the men for about 19 years. 
RELATED: Sexism Could Harm Men's Health 
"We found little change in cardiovascular risk factors for those whose relationships were consistently good or bad," Bennett-Britton said. "But we found a more consistent pattern for those whose relationships had either improved or deteriorated during the study period, with respective improvements and worsening in cardiovascular risk profile." 
Compared with men in "consistently good" relationships, those whose relationships had improved had slightly lower levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, the so-called "bad" type. They also had a slightly lower body mass index , a measurement of body fat based on height and weight, the findings showed. 
"Weaker links were found with improved total cholesterol and improved blood pressure," Bennett-Britton said. 
On the other hand, the investigators found that men in deteriorating relationships had slightly worse blood pressure than those in stable, good relationships. Their diastolic blood pressure, the bottom number in a reading, was, on average, about 3 points higher. 
The researchers reached these numbers after adjusting their statistics to account for variable factors, such as wealth and age. 
Though the possible individual impact of the findings may be small, Bennett-Britton said they could add up to quite a gain in the entire population. 
Still, Potluri noted that the number of men in the study was low and their age was on the young side. The men averaged 36 years old when they first began to be tracked. "The long-term impact of these changes is difficult to ascertain," he said. 
What impact, if any, marriage ups and downs might have on women was not studied. 
For men, though, the possible link between the health of their marriage and the health of their heart could have various origins, the study authors suggested. And the study could not prove a cause-and-effect relationship. 
Patrick Markey, a psychology professor at Villanova University in Pennsylvania, said, "Stress is highly related to physical health, so bad marriages likely cause stress, which causes poor health." 
Also, Markey added, "especially for men, romantic partners often contribute to our physical health more directly. For example, some research in our lab has found that wives often monitor their husband's eating and are more likely to encourage them to eat in a healthy manner. Similarly, wives also appear to be more likely to encourage their husbands to go to doctors, get flu shots and take medication." 
Potluri said another possibility is that worsening health translates to a less happy marriage, and vice versa, but "certainly more evidence is required to address this." 
One thing is clear, though, Markey said: "There is little doubt that people in healthy relationships are, on average, much more healthy than those who are single. Being in a happy relationship is likely good for you both psychologically and physically." 
The study was published online Oct. 9 in the Journal of Epidemiology & Community Health . Last Updated:10/11/2017 Copyright @ 2017 HealthDay . All rights reserved. This site complies with the HONcode standard for trustworthy health information: verify here . × Advertising Notice

thread.title: Your Lungs Get Healthier Every Hour of Every Day After You Quit Smoking | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Your Lungs Get Healthier Every Hour of Every Day After You Quit Smoking | Everyday Health

posts.author: Marty Munson
posts.title: Your Lungs Get Healthier Every Hour of Every Day After You Quit Smoking | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter The beneficial effects of quitting cigarettes starts immediately and lasts for years. Shutterstock 
Lung cancer is the No. 1 cause of cancer deaths for men and women, and 80 to 90 percent of lung cancer cases are linked to cigarette smoke. You might wonder how much difference a day, a week, or a year off cigarettes means to your health, especially if you’re a longtime smoker. Turns out, every increment of time makes a difference in some way. 
1. You’ll feel a difference within hours. Within 12 hours of quitting , the carbon monoxide level in your blood returns to normal. Within 14 to 90 days, your circulation improves and your lung function increases. 
2. Everything will taste and smell better — and you’ll look better, too. Quitters say food tastes better, their sense of smell returns to normal, there’s no lingering cigarette smell on clothes, hair, and breath, and teeth and fingernails stop yellowing and return to a normal color. 
3. Lung cancer risk drops by the year. For every year you don’t smoke, your risk of lung cancer drops. Stay away from smoking for 10 to 15 years, and your chances of this cancer plunge to half of that of current smokers, and they keep going down. When you’ve stayed away from smoking for 30 years, your risk is just 10 to 20 percent of what it is for people who keep up the habit. 
4. Even long term smokers benefit. Men who quit in middle age had only about a 2.5 percent risk of dying from lung cancer by age 75, while those who continue to smoke had an 11 percent risk. Women who quit in their forties had a less than 2 percent chance of dying from lung cancer by age 75, compared with a roughly 6 percent chance if they kept lighting up. 
5. You’re lowering your risk of coronary heart disease, too. Within a year after stubbing out the last cigarette, the risk of coronary heart disease drops to half of that of someone who still smokes — and 15 years after quitting, risk drops to that of a nonsmoker. The likelihood of heart attacks drops , too. 
6. Quitting matters even if you’ve been diagnosed with lung cancer. Research has found that people diagnosed with lung cancer who quit smoking live longer than people who continue to smoke. “Better survival may be a result of several factors, including better response to treatment, lower recurrence rates, and lower risk of developing a second cancer or other disease,” says Eric Jacobs, PhD , strategic director of pharmacoepidemiology at the American Cancer Society.

thread.title: Crohn’s Guide to Navigating Bathrooms Around the World | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Crohn’s Guide to Navigating Bathrooms Around the World | Everyday Health

posts.author: Sheryl Kraft
posts.title: Crohn’s Guide to Navigating Bathrooms Around the World | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Crohn’s Guide to Navigating Bathrooms Around the World Here’s everything you need to know about bathroom etiquette in foreign countries. Sign Up for Our Living with Crohn's Disease Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter You only need to know a few words to do your business globally. Reinhard Krull/Getty Images 
If you’re living with Crohn’s disease, you’ve probably taken note of — or even memorized — every bathroom in every location you’ve ever visited. It is, after all, essential information in case of an emergency. 
But that all changes as soon as you decide to travel, especially if you’re going to a foreign country where you may not even know the word for “bathroom” or how to use the toilet. (Believe me, this can happen.) 
In general you can usually count on places like transportation hubs, historical sites, hotel lobbies, museums and galleries, and department stores to have public restrooms. 
Aside from obvious latrine locations, here are some tips for how to find and properly use toilets around the world. Packing Bathroom Hygiene Products Before You Go 
Prepping for a bathroom emergency while on vacation should start even before you leave home. Be sure to pack things like: Anti-diarrheal medications Cards to communicate your urgent need to use a bathroom, such as the “ I Can’t Wait Card” from the Crohn’s & Colitis Foundation . Spare underwear Toilet paper or gentle wipes Toilet seat covers 
Additionally, it’s always a good idea to evaluate your mode of travel. 
When you reserve your seat on an airplane or train, find out where the closest bathroom is located, and request an aisle seat and special meals where possible. If you’re traveling by bus, check that there is a toilet on board, especially for long trips. 
“It can also be helpful to know your body,” says Jessica Philpott, MD, PhD , a gastroenterologist at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. “If you tend to have bad mornings, then schedule your travel plans for later in the day if possible.” The 411 on Toilets Around the World 
All toilets are not created equal, and range from the basic to the bizarre. The three main kinds of toilets you’ll find around the world are porcelain flush toilets, squat toilets, and luxury latrines. Porcelain flush toilets These are the toilets you’re most likely familiar with, typically found in the United States and most of Europe. Most have seats, but you can’t always take that for granted: Public toilets in some European countries like Greece and Italy may be seatless, and you’ll have to sit on the rim; this gets more common as you go farther south, according to the Toilet Guru . The reason, he says, is that they're easier to keep clean. Squat toilets In much of the world — Asia, the Middle East, Africa, South America, and some older buildings in Europe — people use squat toilets. Squat toilets, also called “Turkish toilets” or “elephant feet” are basically bowls or pans on the floor that you squat over. Some are equipped with a water nozzle (a shower head or hose), or a bucket to fill with water in order to clean off. Some are dry, meaning they don’t flush, and others use a water seal and can be flushed. Luxury latrines Commonly found in Japan, these models are called “intelligent” for many reasons: Their amenities include remote-controlled heated seats, massage functions, bidet, and air-purifying and air-drying functions. Some even check your health, measuring blood pressure, body temperature, and even your weight using a built-in floor scale. And if you’re the self-conscious type, many will supply background music to cover up errant sounds. 
Remember when you're looking for a restroom that it may not be labeled in a way that is familiar. Some bathroom signs are illustrated with recognizable pictures of females and males, or have the initials “WC” (water closet) on their doors. Others will have the word “toilet” in that country's language. Learn the Terminology 
Most travel guidebooks will give you the word or phrase you need to use to ask for a bathroom. Or you can simply google the phrase. Make sure to jot it down and keep it handy, so you can refer to it in a hurry. 
Before you leave: Learn a few key words and phrases in the local language, such as “toilet,” “bathroom,” “urgent,” “emergency,” and “where is.” Travel guidebooks, and the information below, can help make for a pleasant bathroom visit. All About Toilet Paper (TP) 
Just because people use TP doesn’t mean the bathrooms are well stocked with it (or it will be to your liking). Play it safe by carrying pocket-size tissue packs with you. 
Before heading into the stall, take a moment to observe your surroundings: Sometimes there will be a person in the corner selling sheets of toilet paper, notes the travel blogger Rick Steves . Notice whether other people are reaching for paper before they go in, and follow suit. 
And of course, it’s always wise to check the TP situation before sitting down, since you can’t always count on the supply being immediately restocked. 
If there’s a wastebasket next to the toilet with used TP in it, that's a sure sign not to flush, says Steves. Some countries, like Greece and Turkey, have delicate plumbing and moody sewers, and they utilize this method instead of flushing. 
In some areas of Asia, India, and Turkey, the locals don’t use toilet paper — your clue may be a little squirter or small hose near the toilet for rinsing. You’re Making Me Flush 
Flushes come in all shapes and sizes — and locations — and it may be difficult, or even embarrassing, to figure it all out. But flush you must: You don’t want to leave your “evidence” behind. 
Throughout most of Europe, along with the familiar flushers, you’ll also find flushers that require a little thought and sleuthing. (Of course, the easiest type is an automatic flusher that activates once you are finished.) 
Some have a pull string instead of a handle; it’s usually attached to the tank above the toilet. 
Other, more modern bathrooms have two buttons on the top of the tank: One is for regular flushing; the other, which uses less water, is for lighter loads. 
Many bathrooms around Great Britain sport “pump toilets” whose handles are sensitive to the touch and need just the right amount of pressure to get them to work. 
Can’t find a flusher? Look down: Some toilets ( Italy has them) have a metal pedal resembling a car accelerator. Or look sideways and you might see a large white or metal button on the left or right of the toilet. Other times, the flusher can be hidden in the middle of the wall, around knee-level. 
Another type of flusher is a doorknob-like handle on the wall behind the toilet; to work it, you turn it one way or another. 
Many parts of Europe have shared spaces for handwashing, although the men’s and women’s toilet facilities will most likely be separate. Some sinks, rather than having the familiar faucet knobs or levers, have pedals on the floor. To Pay or Not to Pay 
Not all public bathrooms are free, so it’s best to bring change with you when exploring new ground in case you have to pay to heed nature's call. 
Large cities, like Paris, London, and Amsterdam, have bathrooms on street corners that resemble telephone booths. Once you insert the coins, you have 15 minutes to do your thing while you listen to piped-in Muzak. Upon exiting, the bathroom self-disinfects. Then you can breathe in the fresh air and get on with your travels. Last Updated:

thread.title: Grandma Moses Turned to Painting Because of Rheumatoid Arthritis | Everyday Health

posts.author: Cheryl Alkon
posts.title: Grandma Moses Turned to Painting Because of Rheumatoid Arthritis | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Living with Rheumatoid Arthritis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Grandma Moses (1860–1961) didn’t start painting until she was in her seventies. Getty Images 
The woman known as Grandma Moses was a famous American painter known for her 20 th -century folk art style and her own late start — she didn’t start painting extensively until she was 76 years old, and was entirely self-taught. Early Years on a Farm 
Moses, born in 1860 as Anna Mary Robertson in Greenwich, New York, left school at age 12 and worked on a local farm for a wealthy family, where she did housework, cooked, and learned needlework and embroidery. By age 27, she had met and married farmhand Thomas Salmon Moses, and moved with him to run a farm in the Shenandoah Valley in Virginia; later, they moved to Eagle Bridge, New York. Together, Anna and Thomas had ten children, though only five lived past infancy. Self-Expression Through Needlework, Embroidery, and Culinary Arts 
While farming and raising a family were hard work, Anna also spent her time being creative , particularly with needlework and cooking — her jams won awards at local fairs. But pain and health issues ultimately pushed Anna toward painting. Hand Pain and Stiffness Interfered with Sewing 
When she could no longer sew comfortably due to her stiff and painful hands, Anna’s sister Celestia suggested she paint instead, according to V.F. Azevedo in an article published in the journal Rheumatology . As William J. Maloney wrote in the book Diseases, Disorders, and Diagnoses of Historical Individuals , “Inflammation of the small joints of the hand and wrist are common in rheumatoid arthritis . Women are three times more likely to be afflicted than men. Grandma Moses was most likely afflicted with this form of arthritis.” Self-Treating Severe Joint Pain 
In Rheumatology , Azevdo quoted Moses’s efforts to soothe her arthritic hands : “I used to wrap my hands up in scarves and lay them on a chair beside the bed at night. I couldn’t sleep on account of the aching, just like a toothache. Then, one night I got desperate ... [and tried a sweet milk remedy]. I took it for about three months, and all of a sudden, there were no pains anymore, but the hardness of the joints stayed.” Discovering Painting at 70 
Once she began painting, she focused on scenes depicting country life and natural settings. As her collection grew, a relative suggested she hang her work in the window of a local department store in Hoosic Falls, New York, along with other community artwork. It was there that a visiting art collector and dealer saw her work, loved it, and bought it. Making Contemporary Folk Art 
Within a year, three of her paintings were hanging in the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, as part of a contemporary folk art exhibit. By 1940, Anna had her own exhibit of 35 pieces at the Galerie St. Etienne in New York City . At the time of her death in 1961 at age 101, Anna — now known professionally as Grandma Moses — had produced more than 1600 paintings, and was renowned around the world for her style and character. Social and Health Benefits of Making Arts and Crafts 
Painting in a folk art style may be a useful way for older people to cope with aging, counter illness-related isolation , and help prevent depression , a common comorbidity of rheumatoid arthritis. Grandma Moses’s late-life art work may have brought her additional relief, noted Azevedo in Rheumatology . Some specially developed therapeutic art programs for aged rheumatic patients were inspired by Grandma Moses’s example, he explained. 
Besides helping improve the self-esteem of the elderly people, [folk art programs] also foster the communication skills. “To work with folk art in an environment that does not demand a complete mastering of artistic techniques may produce a beneficial effect in rheumatic and depressed elderly people.” Last Updated:

thread.title: What Does Clean Eating Have to Do With Rheumatoid Arthritis? | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: What Does Clean Eating Have to Do With Rheumatoid Arthritis? | Everyday Health

posts.author: Beth Levine
posts.title: What Does Clean Eating Have to Do With Rheumatoid Arthritis? | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Living with Rheumatoid Arthritis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Clean eating, or avoiding processed foods in your diet, may help you lose weight. Jill Chen/Stocksy 
There’s been a lot of buzz lately about “clean eating,” but definitions have been widely divergent and confusing. To set the record straight, clean eating is simply a style of eating — not a strict diet — that aims for optimal health by limiting processed foods. “What we should be looking for is food that is as close to what it looked like when in the ground, on a tree, or swimming in water, and food that has a label with recognizable ingredients and limited additives and preservatives,” says Bonnie Taub-Dix, RDN , author of Read It Before You Eat It. The Importance of a Food’s Origin, Source, and Freshness 
James Loomis, MD , medical director of the nonprofit Barnard Medical Center in Washington, DC, and a representative of The Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine , explains that the food is clean in the sense of what is the ideal diet for human health. “Think about what foods are optimal and then, where do those foods come from. Are they grown cleanly?” Why People With Rheumatoid Arthritis Should Pay Attention to Clean Eating 
The top reasons that a clean diet may help those living with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) stem from the way foods in your regular diet may affect your body and disease activity. 
Omega-6 foods can increase inflammation. The standard American diet is considered highly inflammatory. Most of the inflammation comes from the skewed ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids. The omega-3s, which we don’t eat enough, create compounds that are anti-inflammatory; omega-6s, which we eat too much, create compounds that are considered inflammatory. 
“We need some inflammation to fight infection and fight wounds, but we need a balance. When we get rid of meat and dairy and start to consume fresh fruit, fiber, and whole grains, we bring that ratio back down, and that can help with all autoimmune diseases,” says Dr. Loomis. 
Omega-6 is contained in processed seeds and vegetable oils, especially sunflower, corn, soybean, and cottonseed oils. Omega-3 comes from fatty fish, such as salmon, mackerel, sardines, and tuna, as well as walnuts, flaxseed, and egg yolks. 
Pesticide exposure has been linked to an increased risk of developing autoimmune diseases . A study published in the journal Arthritis Care and Research showed that frequent exposure might increase your risk for developing rheumatoid arthritis and lupus . 
Weight loss can result from eating cleanly . The added bonus to clean eating is that it promotes weight loss, which helps improve joint pain, and can decrease the risks for developing comorbids of RA, such as osteoporosis and heart disease. What a Clean-Eating Diet Looks Like 
Eat local and organic fruits and vegetables. Research suggests that choosing meat from grass-fed, antibiotic-free animals helps lower the omega-6 to omega-3 ratio. 
Balance your plate. The recommendation is that carbs should make up about 50 percent of your diet, protein around 15 to 20 percent, and fat about 30 percent, says Taub-Dix. “When you balance the nutrients in your diet, it enables you to feel more satiated in body and mind so you can eat a cleaner diet. You are less apt to start snacking.” 
Take it easy on salt, sugar, and saturated fats. “People with RA are at increased risk of cardiac disease, so you will help decrease that by reducing your intake of these inflammatory foods . Humans are just not designed to eat processed sugar, salt, and saturated fats,” says Loomis. 
Find your calcium from nondairy sources. Calcium intake is important because it helps decrease the risk of osteoporosis, often a cormorbid disease with RA. But studies have shown that dairy can cause RA symptoms to flare up in response to specific proteins. You can find alternative sources of calcium in plants such as navy beans, Swiss chard, kale, and beet greens. 
Flavor with spices, not sauces. Eating in a less adulterated fashion doesn’t mean the food has to be bland. Instead of covering up your dish with sauces, gravies, or melted cheese, add fresh organic spices to give it a zip and zing. 
Watch what you drink. Those fancy lattes and sodas can add empty calories without actually filling you up. Stay hydrated instead with 100 percent fruit juice diluted with sparkling water or seltzer. Try unsweetened tea with cut-up fruit in it. Put fruit into a water jug. “Afterward you can munch on a fruit, which can be a good speed bump to an unnecessary snack,” says Taub-Dix. 
Don’t get too strict. There has been some backlash against clean eating — that it is too restricting and focuses too much on clean versus dirty food, instead of proportions. Some experts fear that it creates panic around certain so-called toxins and under-recognized sensitivities that either do not exist or are greatly misunderstood. Also, eliminating an entire food group may lead to disordered eating . Taub-Dix cautions that people are interpreting it too strictly. 
She says, "Clean eating really means you are eating food that you can identify, that you can rely on for energy, and will make you feel satiated in your head and body. There are so many fearmongers making people think certain foods are poison. People become overwhelmed so they wind up not knowing what to do. Food shouldn’t be feared, just practice balance and moderation. These are boring words, but they really mean a lot.” Last Updated:

thread.title: New Drug Offers Hope for Patients With Stage 3 Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: New Drug Offers Hope for Patients With Stage 3 Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer | Everyday Health

posts.author: Howard Wolinsky
posts.title: New Drug Offers Hope for Patients With Stage 3 Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Everyday Health Lung Cancer New Drug Offers Hope for Patients With Stage 3 Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Patients who have reached the end of traditional lung cancer treatment options may find success with a new immunotherapy drug. Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter The FDA is reviewing Imfinzi more quickly than usual because of promising study results. Photo Courtesy of AstraZeneca 
New study results presented at the European Society for Medical Oncology meeting in September in Madrid offered the hope of a potential new curative immunotherapy drug — Imfinzi (durvalumab) — for patients with stage 3 non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study results were published online in September 2017 in the New England Journal of Medicine . 
The study, known as the PACIFIC trial, included 700 patients from 26 countries with locally advanced inoperable stage 3 NSCLC whose tumors had not gotten larger or spread after they received chemotherapy and radiation therapy. 
Patients with inoperable stage 3 NSCLC have had few therapy options. Since these tumors cannot be removed surgically, patients have traditionally undergone combined radiation and chemotherapy, an approach with a high rate of recurrent disease and a survival rate of only 25 to 30 percent. 
In the PACIFIC trial, patients received either a placebo or Imfinzi, an antibody checkpoint inhibitor that counters NSCLC tumors’ immune-evading tactics and induces an immune response against the residual tumor cells. 
Subjects receiving Imfinzi had a progression-free survival time — the length of time patients live without the cancer coming back or getting worse — of 16.8 months compared with 5.6 months in the placebo group. The cure rate for the patients in the study has not yet been recorded. 
“For patients with locally advanced unresectable NSCLC who have completed chemoradiation therapy, Imfinzi represents a potential new treatment option in the context of clear unmet clinical need,” says Luis Paz-Ares, MD , the chair of the medical oncology department at the Hospital Doce de Octubre in Madrid, Spain, and the principal investigator of the trial. "Imfinzi overtly prolongs the period in which the disease is controlled with reasonable side effects.” 
Common side effects seen with Imfinzi include muscle and bone pain, fatigue, nausea, constipation, swollen feet and legs, and urinary tract infections; some of these effects were likely a complication of the chemotherapy and radiation subjects received before the Imfinzi. 
Sean Bohen, MD, PhD , the executive vice president for global medicines development and the chief medical officer at AstraZeneca, said the “results are incredibly encouraging for a patient population that until now has been without treatment options. As the first immuno-oncology medicine to achieve improvement in progression-free survival in this setting, Imfinzi is showing clear potential to become a new standard of care for patients with locally advanced, unresectable NSCLC who have not progressed following chemoradiation.” 
In July, the FDA gave Imfinzi Breakthrough Therapy Designation (meaning it will go through a faster review process than usual) as a potential treatment for patients with locally advanced, inoperable NSCLC whose disease has not progressed following platinum-based chemoradiation therapy. And AstraZeneca, the maker of the drug, is in discussions with global health authorities regarding regulatory submissions for Imfinzi based on the PACIFIC data. In May 2017, the FDA gave Imfinzi accelerated approval for previously treated patients with advanced bladder cancer. 
Imfinzi is also being tested as a first-line therapy for stage 4 NSCLC which — for certain patients — is already treated with a similar class of immune-targeted therapy. Last Updated:

posts.author: Mary Elizabeth Dallas
posts.title: Tai Chi: A Gentler Way to Exercise for Ailing Hearts | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Heart Health Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Tai chi exercise can reach low-to-moderate intensity levels. Raoul Minsart/Masterfile 
People with heart disease who shy away from traditional cardiac rehabilitation may benefit from tai chi. 
A small study found that the slow, gentle movements of this traditional Chinese practice may help increase physical activity among those who are reluctant to exercise. 
More than 60 percent of heart attack survivors opt out of cardiac rehabilitation , often because of the perception that the exercise involved will be unpleasant or painful, according to the study authors. 
"We thought that tai chi might be a good option for these people because you can start very slowly and simply and, as their confidence increases, the pace and movements can be modified to increase intensity," said study author Dr. Elena Salmoirago-Blotcher. She is an assistant professor of medicine at the Warren Alpert School of Medicine at Brown University. 
"Tai chi exercise can reach low-to-moderate intensity levels," she explained in a news release from the American Heart Association. "The emphasis on breathing and relaxation can also help with stress reduction and psychological distress." 
Participants in the study included 29 people, age 68 on average, who'd had a heart attack or a procedure to open a blocked artery. All were sedentary, and most had risk factors for heart problems, such as being overweight, smoking or having diabetes or high cholesterol . All of them also had rejected participation in cardiac rehabilitation. 
RELATED: Exercise a Good Prescription to Help Older Hearts 
For the study, they took part in either a short program (24 classes over 12 weeks) or a longer one (52 classes over 24 weeks). All were given a DVD so they could practice tai chi at home. 
Tai chi was found to be safe for the participants with heart disease, with minor muscle pain at the very start the only negative effect. Tai chi also was well-liked by the participants, who all reported they would recommend it to a friend. The researchers said the participants attended 66 percent of classes, suggesting it's a manageable routine. 
Tai chi didn't boost the participants' aerobic fitness levels after three months. But those who completed the longer program did get more moderate to vigorous physical activity on a weekly basis, the study reported. 
The findings were published Oct. 11 in the Journal of the American Heart Association . 
"On its own, tai chi wouldn't obviously replace other components of traditional cardiac rehabilitation, such as education on risk factors, diet and adherence to needed medications," Salmoirago-Blotcher said. 
"If proven effective in larger studies," she said, "it might be possible to offer it as an exercise option within a rehab center as a bridge to more strenuous exercise, or in a community setting with the educational components of rehab delivered outside of a medical setting." thread.title: Lung Cancer Diagnosis Quadruples Suicide Risk | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Lung Cancer Diagnosis Quadruples Suicide Risk | Everyday Health

posts.author: Joseph Bennington-Castro
posts.title: Lung Cancer Diagnosis Quadruples Suicide Risk | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Emotional support is critical for curbing depression, anxiety, and suicidal intentions. Getty Images 
A cancer diagnosis of any type raises a person's risk of suicide. But people diagnosed with lung cancer are at more than four times the risk of the general population, according to a study presented in May at the American Thoracic Society's 2017 international conference in Washington, DC. 
While alarming, the findings are not entirely surprising, says study corresponding author Mohamed Rahouma, MD, a post-doctoral cardiothoracic research fellow at Weill Cornell Medical College and New York Presbyterian Hospital in New York City. 
"We know that lung cancer is an aggressive disease with a low median survival rate," Dr. Rahouma says, adding that the research further showed that suicide appears to be more common in people with advanced stages of lung cancer, which have significantly lower odds of survival than early-stage lung cancer. Study Highlights High Risk for Lung Cancer Patients Among All Patients 
For the study, researchers analyzed cancer-related suicide information from more than 3.5 million people in a large database that spanned four decades. Cancer was associated with nearly 6,700 suicides. The scientists investigated the suicide rate of the four most common non–skin cancers: breast, prostate, lung, and colorectal. 
Compared with the general population, the suicide rate of people with any kind of cancer was 60 percent higher. 
When broken down by type of cancer, the suicide rate of people with breast or prostate cancer was 20 percent higher than the general population and 40 percent higher for colorectal cancer. By comparison, lung cancer corresponded with a 420 percent higher rate of suicide. 
Among those with lung cancer, Asians and men were significantly more likely to take their own lives. Being older, being widowed, refusing surgical treatment, and having cancer that has spread to other areas of the body also increased suicide risk. Findings Support Earlier Research 
The new research falls in line with what previous studies have suggested, says Wolfgang Linden, PhD , a psychologist at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver. 
For example, a previous study published in October 2013 in the journal Chest found that the suicide rate of people with lung cancer is higher than the general population, especially within three months of diagnosis. And in research published in December 2012 in the Journal of Affective Disorders , Dr. Linden and his colleagues found that nearly 25 percent of women with lung cancer were clinically depressed — the highest prevalence rate among cancer types. "Depression goes hand-in-hand with suicidal intentions," Linden says. Many Aspects of the Diagnosis May Play a Role 
Though the new study didn’t look specifically at what causes the high rate of suicide among people with lung cancer, there may be a few possible explanations. 
For one thing, lung cancer is generally asymptomatic until the advanced stages of the disease, so diagnosis often comes late. As such, the five-year survival rate (the percentage of people who survive at least 5 years after diagnosis) for lung cancer is significantly lower than for other common cancers, including prostate and breast cancer. 
“It's pretty easy to convince yourself that you can get through prostate or breast cancer," Linden says. Not so with lung cancer, he adds. 
Additionally, the number one risk factor for lung cancer is cigarette smoking. People diagnosed with the disease who have a history of smoking likely feel a lot of guilt and self-anger knowing that they could have prevented their ailment. The combination of depression from the cancer prognosis and self-anger may be what ultimately drives people over the edge, Linden says. 
Other factors may include co-occurring health issues caused by smoking, such as heart disease, as well as lack of emotional support found in support groups; given the disease's lower cure rates and shorter survival times, there are relatively few support groups for survivors compared with other cancers. Preventing Despair, Offering Support 
For people diagnosed with lung cancer, adequate emotional support is critical for curbing depression, anxiety, and suicidal intentions. 
If you have a family member or friend with lung cancer, you should keep an eye out for signs of depression, including changes in mood, sleep, and appetite. Additionally, you should take an interest in how they're doing and show that you're there for support, but don't press them to do things or try to force them to open up emotionally because this approach could backfire, Linden says. 
"In our practice, we've decided that we need to intervene for those patients that seem at higher risk of suicide," Rahouma says. Upon diagnosing patients, physicians need to ask about the emotional support they have at home or elsewhere, as well as how often they're alone and if they're frequently at home. "If the patient looks to be at a higher risk, we can start to consult with them and refer them to a psychologist." 
Linden agrees that "supportive emotional therapy" from a psychologist is important if you've been recently diagnosed with lung cancer. He stresses that the goal isn't necessarily to completely remove those feelings of sadness and anger, but rather to help you see what you have left to live for. 
"The bottom line is that all our days are counted," Linden says. "Life is full of crappy things that are bound to happen, but if you don't take the time to enjoy the good things, you are missing out on life." Last Updated:

thread.title: Convince a Doctor to Take Rheumatoid Arthritis Symptoms Seriously | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Convince a Doctor to Take Rheumatoid Arthritis Symptoms Seriously | Everyday Health

posts.author: Beth Levine
posts.title: Convince a Doctor to Take Rheumatoid Arthritis Symptoms Seriously | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Living with Rheumatoid Arthritis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Don’t let a dismissive doctor delay your diagnosis. Lumina/Stocksy 
It took Kristen Towery, of Tampa, Florida, more than 20 years to get her rheumatoid arthritis (RA) properly diagnosed. It started in her late twenties when she felt exhausted and had random rashes and other vague symptoms . In her early thirties, her hands started to bother her and the joint symptoms started to spread. She went through many doctors who told her it was all in her head, she was depressed, and should go see a therapist. 
“I knew something was wrong with me, and I knew it wasn’t depression . I just didn’t know if we’d ever find it. It went on so long, the best I was hoping for was that they’d find it when they did my autopsy!” says Towery, who is now a Florida representative for CreakyJoint’s Patient Council . 
She finally got the diagnosis when she saw a rheumatologist who immediately found the rheumatoid arthritis through X-rays. She recalls, “Most people would be devastated but the day I was diagnosed, I was so happy, I was giddy — because I finally I knew what I was dealing with.” Too Many Women on the Medical Battlefront 
Many RA patients can relate to Towery’s story, since most autoimmune patients see five doctors over 4.6 years before they are correctly diagnosed. “Sixty percent will be told they are just chronic complainers,” says Virginia Ladd, president and executive director, American Autoimmune Related Diseases Association (AARDA) . This affects women disproportionately. According to AARDA, 75 percent of those with RA are female, and autoimmune diseases in general are the top killers of women under age 65. Diagnosis Delays Can Be Dangerous 
There are many reasons why this is happening, but the biggest issue is that RA symptoms often tend to be numerous and vague: fatigue , rashes, random pain. “Doctors are uncomfortable with ambiguity. When something is not clear, we become discombobulated, so it is easy to say it’s psychosomatic. And sometimes that might be. But there is some underlying sexism as well — the thinking that women are so menopausal and emotional,” says Danielle Ofri, MD, PhD , author of What Patients Say, What Doctors Hear , and associate professor of medicine at NYU School of Medicine in New York City. 
Ladd adds, “Autoimmune diseases often have an array of symptoms. The fact that you are listing a whole bunch of symptoms, when you are young and look healthy, can throw a physician off. In fact, women doctors are just as likely as male doctors to respond this way." She notes that men with autoimmune diseases who are told it is psychological are significantly fewer, but there are significantly fewer men with these disease as well. Bad Communication Is a Big Part of the Delayed Diagnosis Problem 
Another major problem is that many physicians just don’t take the time to listen to their patients. Research published in the journal Family Medicine found that “patients spoke, uninterrupted, an average of 12 seconds after the resident entered the room. One-fourth of the time, residents interrupted patients before they finished speaking.” Don’t Give Up, Do Fight for a Diagnosis 
If you feel your doctor isn’t listening to you or taking you seriously, here’s what to do: 
Don’t overwhelm the doctor with symptoms. When too many things are thrown at the doctor in one sitting, it becomes hard to see the forest for the trees. “Whittle down the list to what is most important to you and had the most impact on your life. Mention those first and don’t get into the minutiae. Make the doctor ask you for more information, because that engages the doctor,” says Ladd. 
Watch your doctors as they interact with you. “Pay attention to their reactions,” says Dr. Ofri. Are they not even making eye contact because they are staring at their computers? Do they respond to what you are saying? Are they asking the right questions that indicate that they have heard what you’ve said? If you say you have joint pain, do they ask which joint? How often? Are the other questions related to what you are saying? 
Be wary that they are going in the “all in your head” direction. They ask, “Are you under stress or are you happily married?” “That means they are making excuses for your symptoms instead of saying let’s follow you, let’s try this or that and come back in two months. Some things do take time to be diagnosed but it can’t be diagnosed if no one is following you. If your doctor doesn’t set up another appointment, it means he isn’t taking you too seriously,” says Ladd. 
If your general practitioners don’t seem to be paying attention, ask to see a specialist. If they refuse, go to see one on your own. 
Change doctors if you feel dismissed or unheard. “The conversation you have with your doctor is the most important process that you have. Communication is key, especially in rheumatoid diseases ,” says Ofri. Be Sure to Self-Treat Carefully and Responsibly 
Many frustrated RA patients are tempted to self-treat, which can be good and bad. Most of the supplements are harmless and there can be a placebo effect, but be sure you are honest with your physician about what you are taking. Ofri says, “Work with your doctor, don’t try to hide it. Some of these alternative therapies may work, but there can be toxicities that we don’t know about. Also, the supplement might not contain what it says it contains. If your doctors are really listening to you, they should be able to integrate complementary healing .” Believe in Yourself, Advocate for Yourself 
“It comes down to: You have to believe in yourself, your own experience, and fight for proper d iagnosis . You can’t give up. You have to realize that your doctor is not in charge of your personal health — you are. If that doctor is not giving you the answers you want, but you know there is something wrong, it is your responsibility to keep going and advocate for yourself,” says Towery. Last Updated:

Sign Up for Our Living with Rheumatoid Arthritis Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Fight flu with easy-to-use hand-washing and fingernail-cleaning tools. Photos Courtesy of OXO Good Grips 
How clean are your hands and fingernails? Flu season peaks anywhere from late November through March, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) , and keeping hands clean and hygienic is one of the most important ways to avoid getting sick. Even when you act early and get the influenza shot , it takes two weeks after vaccination for your body to create the antibodies that protect against flu. How to Prevent Flu Despite Rheumatoid Arthritis Joint Pain 
Since people with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are especially vulnerable to flu-related infections , flu prevention is key. But frequent hand-washing can be a drag when your hands are painful or swollen, a frequent RA symptom. Why? Hands contain many small joints, quite of a few containing the synovial tissue most often attacked by RA. Regular cleaning gadgets that require a certain level of manual dexterity can be, literally, a pain for those with RA. Soap Dispensers Designed With Arthritis Symptoms In Mind 
“People with arthritis and tender joints are so appreciative and loyal to brands and products that make their lives easier,” says Marcy O’Koon, senior director for consumer health at the Arthritis Foundation . She suggests checking out the Arthritis Foundation Ease of Use program for products tested by ergonomic experts and a panel of people with arthritis (look for the Ease-of-Use Commendation on labels). “The process includes a real-world review by a panel of people with arthritis. All too often, products that are not arthritis-friendly are actually not ‘people-friendly,’ meaning they are actually difficult for everybody to use.” 
Until the Arthritis Foundation program includes a hand-washing recommendation, consider these options. These four easy-to-use soap dispensers — and one scrub brush — will help you clean up nice, in more ways than one. OXO Good Grips Soap Dispenser 
$10.00, OXO.com 
The large button on this budget buy makes applying soap simple. The wide opening is easy to refill, and it’s available in charcoal or white. MaxiAids Touch Free Soap Dispenser 
$15.00, MaxiAids.com 
This stainless dispenser works with liquid soap (or lotion and antibacterial gel) and is easy to load. Batteries are required (4 AAA), but no repeated squeezing or pressing is needed thanks to the infrared sensor. OXO Good Grips Big Button Soap Dispenser 
$20.00, OXO.com 
Get soapy at the touch of a big (soft) button (it also works for dish soap or lotion). The window and wide opening make for easy refills. Stainless with a nonskid base. Kohler Touchless Foaming Soap Dispenser 
$67.00, us.Kohler.com 
This sleek, no-touch option uses foaming or liquid soap, and comes in trend-friendly stainless or white. An anti-drip spout helps keep counters clean. A window lets you know when it’s time for a refill. Kids (and impatient adults) will love the 20-second light that helps them lather up long enough . Mounted Finger Scrub Brush 
$7.00, ArthritisSupplies.com 
Don’t forget to keep your fingernail squeaky clean. Scrubbing under nails helps banish the bacteria and dirt that lurk there. If you have difficulty gripping a brush, try using one that adheres to your counter or sink with powerful suction cups. Last Updated:

thread.title: A Lung Cancer Survivor Celebrates by Taking on Stigma | Everyday Health

posts.author: Laurie Tarkan
posts.title: A Lung Cancer Survivor Celebrates by Taking on Stigma | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Sign Up for Our Cancer Care and Prevention Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter We respect your privacy . Loss is participating in the Lungevity Breathe Deep DC Walk in Washington, DC, on November 5. 
When Karen Loss, 57, tells people that she has lung cancer, she always braces for the inevitable question: “Are you a smoker?” She isn’t, and never has been, but ever since she was diagnosed with non-small-cell lung cancer in 2012, it’s one of the most common questions she faces. She tries not to get annoyed. She’s learned through experience that lung cancer carries a stigma because of its association with smoking, and that people are misinformed. 
That’s one of the main reasons Loss decided to become an advocate and educator, and why she’ll be walking for the fourth year in the Lungevity Breathe Deep Walk fundraiser . “People think that if they didn’t smoke, they’re not at risk of lung cancer,” she says. “I have two responses to this. One, anyone who has lungs is potentially at risk, and two, even smokers deserve compassion just like the rest of us,” she says. 
“My goal is to spread awareness about the disease, because there’s a lot unintentional ignorance surrounding it,” says Loss. An estimated 10 to 20 percent of people who die from lung cancer were never smokers. A Delayed Diagnosis 
This kind of misconception about lung cancer may have delayed Loss’s own diagnosis. “I’m not a smoker and I had symptoms that didn’t make me or anyone else think lung cancer,” she says. She had what she calls, “chest attacks,” feeling like a rubber band was constricting her chest, which would last for a day or so and then go away. The only other symptom was that her voice was raspy. 
She first went to a gastroenterologist, who looked for heartburn, hernias, and other causes of her symptoms. Finally, her doctor ordered a CAT scan to image her gallbladder. Her gallbladder was fine, it turned out, but her lungs were not. The scan caught the tumor, which was categorized as stage IV, the most advanced stage. 
Lung cancer is often diagnosed at a late stage, because it’s only in the late stages that symptoms first appear. The diagnosis can get further delayed in patients, like Loss, who are not smokers, because even physicians tend not to consider lung cancer as a diagnosis in nonsmokers. It’s not unusual for tumors to show up on scans ordered for other reasons. A Positive Outlook 
Loss was surprised by her diagnosis, but she knew how to cope. This was the second time around for her. When she was 36, she was diagnosed with ovarian and uterine cancer, which was treated successfully. In some ways, she says, her diagnosis “was probably easier for me because I had some experience with cancer.” She says her religious faith and a determined optimism has sustained her through the difficult treatments. 
“I am a firm believer in trying to maintain a positive attitude toward living with cancer. It won’t necessarily lengthen one’s life,” she says, “but it will make living easier and better.” 
Loss documented her cancer treatments and thoughts in a book, Trekking Through Cancerland , which started as a weekly email update to friends and family. It covers the first nine months after she was diagnosed with lung cancer and walks readers through the ups and downs of her treatment. Advocating for Clinical Trials 
In November, she will reach the five-year anniversary of her diagnosis, putting her in a very small group of survivors. The five-year survival rate for people diagnosed with stage IV non-small-cell lung cancer is less than 1 percent. She is not “cured,” though. 
Loss is currently in an experimental trial of an immunotherapy drug, and one of her advocacy goals is to encourage others to do the same. 
“Clinical trials in lung cancer are very important for an awful lot of us, but only about 3 percent of cancer patients participate in them,” she says. For Loss, participating in clinical trials may increase her chance of survival, but also helps provide scientific data that will benefit future cancer patients. posts.author: Amy Norton
posts.title: Dance Your Way to a Healthier Aging Brain | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Dance Your Way to a Healthier Aging Brain Small study suggests it might boost memory, learning. Sign Up for Our Healthy Living Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Older adults who took weekly dance classes showed gains in their balancing ability. Tom Stewart/Getty Images 
Dance classes may beat traditional exercise when it comes to improving older adults' balance -- and it might enhance brain areas related to memory and learning along the way. 
That's the finding of a small study that compared dance lessons against standard exercise -- including brisk walking -- among 52 healthy seniors. 
Over a year and a half, older adults who took weekly dance classes showed gains in their balancing ability. There were no such improvements in the traditional exercise group. 
Researchers also found hints that all those mambos and cha-chas had extra brain benefits. 
Seniors in both groups showed growth in the hippocampus -- a brain structure that's involved in memory and learning. But the dancers showed changes in more areas of the hippocampus. 
Patrick Muller, one of the researchers on the study, suggested an explanation: The "multimodal" nature of dance -- its physical and mental components -- might be behind the extra brain boost. 
Seniors in the dance group had to continually learn and "imprint" new steps, explained Muller, a Ph.D. candidate at the German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases in Magdeburg, Germany. 
Along with that mental challenge, he said, dance also involves coordinating movement with music -- which itself affects the brain. Plus, there's the fun, Muller noted. 
RELATED: The 15 Most Common Health Concerns for Seniors 
David Marquez is an associate professor of kinesiology at the University of Illinois at Chicago. He said it's hard to know what to make of the brain findings, since the study group was so small. 
Marquez, who was not involved in the research, is studying the effects of Latin dance classes on older Hispanic adults' well-being. 
He agreed that dance can offer things that simpler repetitive activity may not. 
"With dance, you're having to think about each step," Marquez said. "There are motor, cognitive and social components . And there's the music." 
But, he added, both exercise groups in this study showed changes in the hippocampus, on average. And that's in line with past research, Marquez noted: Studies have found that regular aerobic exercise, like walking, may boost the volume of brain areas involved in memory, planning and other vital functions. 
"So the message is, get moving," Marquez said. 
Ultimately, he added, the "best" form of exercise for any one person is the one that can be maintained. 
"If you don't enjoy the activity, you won't do it," Marquez said. "So find something you enjoy and do it regularly." 
The study, published in Frontiers in Human Neuroscience , included healthy volunteers who were typically in their late 60s. 
Half were randomly assigned to take dance classes over 18 months. The rest attended a traditional exercise program that included walking, stationary bikes, strength-training and stretching. 
The dance group met twice a week for the first six months, then weekly. To keep participants on their toes, the dance styles changed every couple of weeks and ranged from Latin to line dancing to jazz. 
Just 14 seniors from the dance group and 12 from the traditional fitness group stayed with the program for the full 18 months. 
In the end, the study found, only the dancers showed clear improvements on balance tests. And while both groups had increases in their hippocampal volume, the dance group tended to show changes in more subregions of the hippocampus. 
The hippocampus is critical, according to Muller, because it is affected in dementia -- including Alzheimer's disease -- and it can also shrink with age. 
The big question, though, is whether dance can make any difference in the odds of seniors' mental decline. 
"Further research is needed to clarify whether this intervention truly has the potential to reduce the risk of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's," Muller said. 
According to Marquez, it would be interesting to do the same study with older adults who already have some cognitive impairment, and see if there are similar brain changes. 
For now, Muller said, the findings suggest dance might have some advantages over simpler repetitive physical activity. 
But he agreed that exercise in general -- plus a healthy lifestyle overall -- "can help the brain stay young." Last Updated:10/16/2017 Copyright @ 2017 HealthDay . All rights reserved. thread.title: Daily 'Light Therapy' May Help Some With Bipolar Disorder | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Daily 'Light Therapy' May Help Some With Bipolar Disorder | Everyday Health

posts.author: Robert Preidt
posts.title: Daily 'Light Therapy' May Help Some With Bipolar Disorder | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Daily 'Light Therapy' May Help Some With Bipolar Disorder Study found an hour in front of a light box helped ease depressive symptoms. Sign Up for Our Mental Health & Mood Disorders Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Light therapy can sometimes cause side effects, such as mania, in people with bipolar disorder. Corbis 
People afflicted with bipolar disorder may find some relief from depression with daily doses of light therapy, new research suggests. 
With light therapy, people spend time sitting in close proximity to a light-emitting box -- in this case, bright white light -- with exposures increasing from 15 minutes per day to a full hour over a period of weeks. 
The study found that within a month the therapy helped treat depression in people with bipolar disorder . 
"Effective treatments for bipolar depression are very limited," noted lead researcher Dr. Dorothy Sit. 
"This gives us a new treatment option for bipolar patients that we know gets us a robust response within four to six weeks," said Sit, who is associate professor of psychiatry at Northwestern University in Chicago. 
According to the Brain & Behavior Research Foundation, bipolar disorder "is a brain and behavior disorder characterized by severe shifts in a person's mood and energy, making it difficult for the person to function." Over 5.7 million Americans are thought to have the disorder, which often involves depressive episodes. 
As Sit's team noted, prior research had shown that morning light therapy reduces symptoms of depression in people with seasonal affective disorder (SAD) , a condition where winter's reduced light spurs depression. 
However, it's also been noted that light therapy can sometimes cause side effects, such as mania, in people with bipolar disorder. 
RELATED: 10 Celebrities With Depression, Bipolar Disorder, or Both 
Still, the Northwestern team wondered if the treatment might not have a role for bipolar patients with at least moderate depression who were also taking a mood stabilizer drug. 
In the study, 46 patients received either a 7,000 lux bright white light or a 50 lux light (acting as the "placebo arm" of the trial). 
The study participants were told to place the light box about one foot from their face for 15 minutes between noon and 2:30 p.m. each day at the start of the study. 
Over six weeks, the patients increased their light therapy "doses" in 15-minute increments until they reached a dose of 60 minutes per day -- or had a significant change in their mood. 
Compared with people in the placebo group, those in the treatment group were more likely to have significant improvements, Sit's team said. 
More than 68 percent of patients in the treatment group achieved a normal mood versus 22 percent of those in the placebo group, the findings showed. Patients in the treatment group also had a much lower average depression score than those in the placebo group, and significantly higher functioning, meaning they could return to work or complete household tasks they hadn't been able to finish before treatment. 
Significantly, none of the patients experienced mania or hypomania , a condition that includes a period of elation, euphoria, irritability, agitation, rapid speech, racing thoughts, a lack of focus and risk-taking behaviors. 
"As clinicians, we need to find treatments that avoid these side effects and allow for a nice, stable response. Treatment with bright light at midday can provide this," Sit said in a university news release. 
Two psychiatrists agreed that the therapy may have merit for patients, who often have few options. 
"No standard antidepressants are approved for treatment of bipolar depression," said Dr. Seth Mandel, who directs psychiatry at Northwell Health's Huntington Hospital in Huntington, N.Y. He added that antipsychotics that are approved for bipolar disorder often come with side effects that cause many patients to stop using them. 
Light therapy "offers us another option, one that certainly appears to do no harm," Mandel said. 
Still, he noted that patients with more severe symptoms weren't included in the Chicago study, and he also believes many people won't be able to adhere to the hour-long, daily dosage required. 
Dr. Ami Baxi is a psychiatrist who directs adult inpatient services at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. She agreed that light therapy may be "a welcome addition to our limited treatment options for bipolar depression." 
The study was funded by the U.S. National Institute of Mental Health and published Oct. 3 in the American Journal of Psychiatry . Last Updated:10/16/2017 Copyright @ 2017 HealthDay . thread.title: Can Doctor Review Websites Help You Find a Crohn’s Specialist? | Everyday Health
thread.title_full: Can Doctor Review Websites Help You Find a Crohn’s Specialist? | Everyday Health

posts.author: Quinn Phillips
posts.title: Can Doctor Review Websites Help You Find a Crohn’s Specialist? | Everyday Health
posts.text:
Everyday Health Crohn's Disease Can Doctor Review Websites Help You Find a Crohn’s Specialist? Despite their promises, doctor review sites face a number of problems and limitations. Here’s how to find a gastroenterologist instead. Sign Up for Our Living with Crohn's Disease Newsletter Thanks for signing up! You might also like these other newsletters: 
Sign up for more FREE Everyday Health newsletters . Oops! Please enter a valid email address Sign up Oops! Please enter a valid email address Oops! Please select a newsletter Don't rely too heavily on doctor review websites when looking for a gastroenterologist. Shutterstock 
Before the internet, people in search of a new gastroenterologist usually had to rely on word-of-mouth recommendations from other doctors, family members, or friends. Of course, many people still look for a doctor this way, but for several years, there have also been websites and other online tools available where you can read and write reviews of doctors in your area. Can these websites really connect you with the care you need? 
In a word, no — for a variety of reasons. One is that there still isn’t any online hub where you’re likely to find all the information you care about when looking for a doctor. Many commercial websites that offer doctor ratings, such as Healthgrades, Vitals, and Yelp, don’t let you easily search by insurance plan or hospital network, and often don’t offer much information on the focus of a doctor’s practice, such as the conditions they specialize in treating. 
Then there’s the question of how much you should trust or rely on the reviews that people post on doctor-rating websites. One major limitation of commercial doctor-rating websites is that most doctors in a given area probably aren’t listed on them, and among those that are listed, there probably won’t be many reviews. It’s also important to remember that reviews are subjective, so you might not even get the information you’re seeking. 
Also, because it’s important to find a doctor with whom you can discuss personal and oftentimes embarrassing Crohn’s symptoms, you might want to tread carefully when relying on doctor review websites. 3 Things to Know Before Scheduling an Appointment 1. Not a Lot of People Actually Post Ratings 
As noted in a study published in February 2017 in the journal JAMA , among doctors with at least one review on any of the main commercial sites, the median number of reviews of that doctor was just 7 — across all the sites. This isn’t a large enough number to get much of an overall impression of an MD, especially when you consider that some of these reviews may have been written by the same person on different sites. 
“Even though these sites have really good intentions, they haven’t fulfilled the promises that they made initially,” says Tara Lagu, MD , a research scientist in the Center for Quality of Care Research at Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Massachusetts, who coauthored the JAMA study. 
“I think it’s partly that the sites are not great,” Dr. Lagu says, “partly that patients hesitate to write reviews, and partly that the numbers aren’t sufficient” when it comes to how many patients a doctor typically sees, compared with the number of people who do things like visit restaurants and buy appliances — areas in which reviews are much easier to come by. 
Lagu believes there may be a simple explanation for why people are more hesitant to review their doctors than other services. “Reviewing your doctor is like reviewing your mother,” she says. “You’re probably going to give your mother a mixed review, but overall, you’re most interested in preserving the relationship. So overall, you’re going to hesitate to say anything negative.” 2. Not All Local Doctors Are Included on Rating Sites 
On all of the major commercial doctor rating sites, you can search for a doctor based on their name, location, or specialty. Some also let you search based on a condition or procedure, or a hospital where the doctor works. 
It’s often very difficult, though, to find out what insurance a doctor accepts, and not possible on most of the major sites to search based on this information. Some sites have a tab on each doctor’s profile for insurance carriers or plans accepted, but this information may be incomplete or missing. And searching for doctors in your area, then clicking around to find out if a particular one accepts your insurance, is hardly an efficient way to get this information. 
It’s also worth noting that when you do a location-based search on any of these sites, you’re not going to find every doctor in your area who fits your search criteria — just the ones with a profile on that site. Depending on where you live, this can be extremely limiting, with potentially only a handful of doctors nearby showing up in your search. And even if you live in a major metropolitan area, your search is likely to leave out many qualified doctors. 
You’re also likely to be directed to doctors with the highest ratings, rather than just those closest to you, when you do a location-based search. This makes a certain amount of sense — after all, these ratings are probably a major reason why you’re on the site. But you may miss a nearby doctor with only a couple of ratings, potentially placing them lower on the list of search results. 3. Ratings Are Highly Subjective 
Let’s say you’ve done a search, found a doctor who appears to fit your basic needs, and are now browsing the doctor’s ratings and reviews. A large number of positive scores or comments is a good sign, right? 
Possibly — but it should be telling that especially among doctors with many more reviews than others, the comments tend to be overwhelmingly positive. This probably isn’t because the doctor has many more happy patients than other doctors, or happens to see more patients who decide to write reviews. Instead, there’s a good chance that the doctor’s office is encouraging patients to write reviews — possibly in a selective manner. 
Even assuming that a review isn’t solicited or biased in any way, what exactly is a patient reviewing? Most likely, it’s the overall experience of their visit: whether they were seen in a timely manner, how receptive the doctor was to their concerns, and whether they got a diagnosis or treatment they were looking for. 
While it’s perfectly fine to care about these factors, a patient is unlikely to have the expertise to judge a doctor’s skill or competence beyond a basic level, and even if this were possible, a handful of reviews doesn’t tell you much about a doctor’s overall track record. 
In fact, there’s some evidence that online reviews don’t reflect a doctor’s overall performance. Researchers at ConsumerMedical , a healthcare support and concierge company, did a comparison of doctor ratings on commercial sites with doctors’ actual performance data — such as hospital readmission and infection rates, and other measurable outcomes — within five medical specialties, including gastroenterology, in three major U.S. cities. They found that only 2 percent of top-ranked doctors on the sites were also top-ranked based on outcomes. 
“Unfortunately, patient-generated reviews just don’t work that well when it comes to picking doctors,” says Sue Lewis , chief product and strategy officer at ConsumerMedical. “Very little exists out there that helps patients choose a high-quality physician.” 
So where does this leave those of us who want access to useful ratings tools that are as objective as possible? 
Lewis notes that some health insurance plans have a directory that includes some measures of doctor performance, but that this feature tends not to be advertised widely to members. So it’s worth checking out your plan’s online search function to see if anything like this exists. How to Improve Doctor Review Sites for the Future 
When it comes to reviews by patients, Lagu believes the wave of the future may be a public website incorporating the results of surveys designed by the federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality , which are already widely administered across the country. Planning for such a site is already under way, Lagu notes, adding that such a site would incorporate the experiences of a large, random sample of patients. 
A handful of health systems — notably University of Utah Health — already post the results of these surveys on their doctor profiles, yielding far more reviews than exist on most commercial sites. 
In the meantime, if you’re intent on looking at doctor reviews, read as many as you can before making an appointment, and take what you read, positive or negative, with a grain of salt. And even if it seems hopelessly old-fashioned, you may also want to ask friends, family, or a doctor you trust for recommendations. Word of mouth may not be perfect, but neither are the newer methods of finding a doctor.
